{{Year nav topic5|1707|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1707'''.
==Events== *[[March 8]] – [[George Farquhar]]'s [[Restoration comedy]] ''[[The Beaux' Stratagem]]''<ref name=cocel>{{cite book|editor=Cox, Michael|title=The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-860634-6}}</ref> is first staged, at the [[Theatre Royal, Haymarket]] in London. *[[May 1]] – The new sovereign [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] comes into being under the [[Acts of Union 1707|Acts of Union]], which combine the [[Kingdom of England]] and the [[Kingdom of Scotland]] into a one realm under [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain]], with the support of [[Daniel Defoe]] and [[John Arbuthnot]]. *[[September 9]] – [[Richard Steele]] marries [[Mary Steele|Mary Scurlock]] – a most famous literary marriage, thanks to their correspondence. *Controversial publisher [[Edmund Curll]] announces he will publish [[Matthew Prior]]'s ''Poems on Several Occasions'' even though the rights belong to someone else.
==New books== <!-- (''Title of published book translation''), ("Title of published poem/story translation"), (Literal translation of title) --> ===Prose=== *Anonymous **''Memoirs of the Court of England'' (translation)<ref name=cocel/> **''The History of the Earl of Warwick; Sirnam'd the King-maker'' (transl.)<ref name=cocel/> *[[Richard Baxter]] – ''The Poetical Works of the Late Richard Baxter''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Tom Brown (satirist)|Thomas Brown]] – ''The Works of Mr Thomas Brown''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Anthony Collins]] – ''Essay Concerning the Use of Reason''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Jean de Beaugué]] – ''Histoire de la guerre d'Ecosse'' (translation by [[Patrick Abercromby]]) *[[François Pétis de la Croix]] (translated and adapted) – ''Contes Turcs'' (Turkish Tales) *[[Thomas D'Urfey]] – ''Stories, Moral and Comical''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Laurence Echard]] – ''The History of England'' vol. 1<ref name=cocel/> *[[Aaron Hart (rabbi)|Aaron Hart]] – ''Urim v'tumim'' (the first book printed in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] in [[London]])<ref>{{cite web|first=Andrew Colin|last=Gow|title=Hart, Aaron (1670–1756)|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/12467|accessdate=2011-12-09}} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> *[[Edward Lhuyd]] – ''Archaeologia Britannica: an Account of the Languages, Histories and Customs of Great Britain...'' *[[Delarivière Manley]] – ''The Lady's Pacquet of Letters'' (fiction)<ref name=cocel/> *[[Isaac Newton]] – ''[[Arithmetica Universalis]]'' *[[John Oldmixon]] – ''The Muses Mercury'' (periodical)<ref name=cocel/> *[[Matthäus Schiner]], ''A Philippick Oration to Incite the English Against the French'' (translated by [[John Toland]]) *Dr. [[Thomas Smith (scholar)|Thomas Smith]] – ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=4D_4D3qRCdoC&source=gbs_navlinks_s Vitæ quorundam Eruditissimorum et Illustrium Virorum]'' *[[Jonathan Swift]] – ''A Critical Essay upon the Faculties of the Mind'' *[[Matthew Tindal]] – ''A Defence of the Rights of the Christian Church'' (sequel to [[1706 in literature|1706]] work)<ref name=cocel/> *[[Catherine Trotter Cockburn|Catherine Trotter]] – ''A Discourse Concerning a Guide in Controversies''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Isaac Watts]] – ''Hymns and Spiritual Songs'' (frequently reprinted)<ref name=cocel/> *[[John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester]] – ''The Miscellaneous Works of the Late Earls of Rochester and Roscommon''<ref name=cocel/>
===Drama=== *[[Joseph Addison]] – ''Rosamund'' (opera)<ref name=cocel/> *[[Susanna Centlivre]] – ''The Platonick Lady''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Colley Cibber]] **''The Lady's Last Stake''<ref name=cocel/> **''The Double Gallant''<ref name=cocel/> *[[Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon]] – ''Atrée et Thyeste'' *[[George Farquhar]] – ''[[The Beaux' Stratagem]]'' *[[Alain-René Lesage]] – ''[[Crispin rival de son maître]]'' *[[Peter Anthony Motteux]] – ''Thomyris, Queen of Scythia'' (opera)<ref name=cocel/> *[[Nicholas Rowe (dramatist)|Nicholas Rowe]] – ''The Royal Convert'' *[[Nahum Tate]] – ''Injur'd Love'' (an adaptation of [[John Webster|Webster]]'s ''[[The White Devil]]'')<ref name=cocel/>
===Poetry=== {{main article|1707 in poetry}} *[[Samuel Cobb (poet)|Samuel Cobb]] – ''Poems on Several Occasions'' *[[John Pomfret]] – ''Quae Rara, Chara'' (poem) *[[Nahum Tate]] – ''The Triumph of Union''<ref name=cocel/>
==Births== *[[January 13]] – [[John Boyle, 5th Earl of Cork]], English writer (died [[1762 in literature|1762]]) *[[February 14]] – [[Claude Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon]], French novelist (died [[1777 in literature|1777]]) *[[February 25]] – [[Carlo Goldoni]], Venetian dramatist (died [[1793 in literature|1793]]) *[[April 20]] – [[Robert Foulis (printer)|Robert Foulis]], Scottish printer and publisher (died [[1776 in literature|1776]]) *[[April 22]] – [[Henry Fielding]], English novelist (died [[1754 in literature|1754]]) *[[June 22]] ''(baptized)'' – [[Elizabeth Blackwell (illustrator)|Elizabeth Blackwell]], Scottish botanic writer and illustrator (died [[1758 in literature|1758]]) *[[August 14]] – [[Johann August Ernesti]], German philologist (died [[1781 in literature|1781]]) *[[September 7]] – [[Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon]], French philosopher (died [[1788 in literature|1788]]) *[[December 18]] – [[Charles Wesley]], English hymnist, religious writer and cleric (died [[1788 in literature|1788]])
==Deaths== *[[January 20]] – [[Humphrey Hody]], English theologian (born [[1659 in literature|1659]]) *[[April 20]] – [[George Farquhar]], Irish dramatist (born [[1677 in literature|1677]]) *[[June 23]] – [[John Mill (theologian)|John Mill]], English theologian and exegete (born c. 1645) *[[September 15]] – [[George Stepney]], English poet and diplomat (born [[1663 in literature|1663]]) *[[September 23]] – [[John Tutchin]], English controversialist (born c. 1660–64) *[[September 24]] – [[Vincenzo da Filicaja]], Italian poet (born [[1642 in literature|1642]]) *[[December 27]] – [[Jean Mabillon]], French scholar (born [[1632 in literature|1632]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Alexandre Exquemelin]], French or Flemish writer on piracy (born c. 1645)
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1707 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 18th century in literature]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} {{Year nav topic5|1738|literature|poetry}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1738'''.
==Events== *[[April 11]] – [[Robert Blair (poet)|Robert Blair]] marries Isabella Law. *[[July 10]] – [[Richard Dawes]] is appointed master of the [[Royal Grammar School, Newcastle]]. *August – [[Laurence Sterne]] is ordained a priest, and in the autumn becomes vicar of [[Sutton-on-the-Forest]]. *Beginning of the mental decline of [[Jonathan Swift]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Will|last=Durant|authorlink=Will Durant|title=[[The Story of Civilization]]|volume=8}}</ref> *''[[Samtal emellan Argi Skugga och en obekant Fruentimbers Skugga]]'' by [[Margareta Momma]]
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[James Anderson (Freemason)|James Anderson]] – ''[[History of Freemasonry#Anderson's Constitutions|The Constitutions of the Free-Masons]]'', 2nd ed. *[[John Bancks|John Banks]] – ''Miscellaneous Works in Verse and Prose'' *[[Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten]] – ''De ordine in audiendis philosophicis per triennium academicum quaedam praefatus acroases proximae aestati destinatas indicit Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten'' *[[Louis de Beaufort]] – ''Dissertation sur l'incertitude des cinq prèmiers siècles de l'histoire romaine'' *[[Alexander Cruden]] – ''A Complete Concordance to the Holy Scriptures of the Old and New Testament'' *[[Robert Dodsley]] – ''The Art of Preaching'' *[[David Hume]] (anonymously) – ''[[A Treatise of Human Nature]]'' (dated 1739) *[[Pierre Louis Maupertuis]] – ''Sur la figure de la terre'' *[[Abbé Prévost]] – ''Memoirs of a Man of Quality'' (anonymous English translation) *[[Jonathan Swift]] **''The Beasts Confession to the Priest'' **''[[A Complete Collection of Genteel and Ingenious Conversation]]'' *[[William Warburton]] **''[[The Divine Legation of Moses Demonstrated]]'' **''A Vindication of the author of the Divine Legation of Moses'' *[[George Whitefield]] – ''A Journal of a Voyage from London to Savannah in Georgia'' *[[Diego de Torres Villarroel]] **''Anatomía de todo lo visible e invisible'' **''Vida ejemplar de la venerable madre Gregoria Francisca de Santa Teresa''
===Drama=== *[[Robert Dodsley]] – ''Sir John Cockle at Court'' *[[Carlo Goldoni]] **''Momolo Cortesan'' **''L'uomo di mondo'' *Sir [[Hildebrand Jacob]] **''The Happy Constancy'' **''The Prodigal Reformed'' **''The Trial of Conjugal Love'' *[[George Lillo]] – ''Marina'' (adapted from [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Pericles, Prince of Tyre]]'') *[[James Miller (playwright)|James Miller]] – ''Art and Nature'' *[[António José da Silva]] – ''Precipicio de Faetonte'' *[[James Thomson (poet)|James Thomson]] – ''Agamemnon''
===Poetry=== *[[Mark Akenside]] (anonymously) – ''A British Philippic'' *[[Elizabeth Carter]] (anonymously) – ''Poems Upon Particular Occasions'' *[[John Gay]] – ''Fables: Volume the Second'' *[[Eugenio Gerardo Lobo]] – ''Obras poéticas líricas'' *[[Samuel Johnson]] – ''London, A Poem, on the Third Satire of Juvenal'' *[[Alexander Pope]] **''The Sixth Epistle of the First Book of Horace Imitated'' **''The First Epistle of the First Book of Horace Imitated'' **(with [[Jonathan Swift]]) ''An Imitation of the Sixth Satire of the Second Book of Horace'' **''One Thousand Seven Hundred and Thirty Eight'' **''The Universal Prayer'' **''One Thousand Seven Hundred and Thirty Eight: Dialogue II'' *[[James Thomson (poet)|James Thomson]] – ''The Works of Mr Thomson'' *[[Diego de Torres Villarroel]] – ''Juguetes de Talia, entretenimiento del numen'' *[[John Wesley]] – ''A Collection of Psalms and Hymns'' (first English edition)
==Births== *[[February 9]] ''(baptised)'' – [[Mary Whateley]], English poet and playwright (died [[1825 in literature|1825]]) *[[May 9]] – [[John Wolcot]], English satirist and poet (died [[1819 in literature|1819]]) *[[May 12]] – [[Jonathan Boucher]], English philologist (died [[1804 in literature|1804]]) *[[May 27]] – [[Moritz August von Thümmel]], German humorist and satirical author (died [[1817 in literature|1817]]) *[[June 21]] – [[Gottlieb Christoph Harless]], German bibliographer (died [[1815 in literature|1815]]) *[[July 24]] – [[Betje Wolff]], Dutch novelist (died 1804) *[[November 15]] – [[Joseph Johnson (publisher)|Joseph Johnson]], English publisher (died [[1809 in literature|1809]]) *[[December 4]] – Karl Friedrich Kretschmann, [[German poetry|German]] poet, playwright and storyteller (died 1809) *''Unknown date'' – [[Manuel Lassala]], Spanish dramatist and philosopher (died [[1806 in literature|1806]])
==Deaths== *[[January 6]] – [[Jean-Baptiste Labat]], French polymath (born [[1663 in literature|1663]]) *March – [[Margrethe Lasson]], Danish novelist (born [[1659 in literature|1659]]) *[[April 25]] – [[Giacomo Laderchi]], Italian ecclesiastical historian (born c. 1678) *[[June 5]] – [[Isaac de Beausobre]], French theologian (born [[1659 in literature|1659]]) *[[July 8]] – [[Jean-Pierre Nicéron]], French lexicographer (born [[1685 in literature|1685]]) *[[September 4]] – [[George Lillo]], English playwright (born [[1691 in literature|1691]]) *[[September 23]] – [[Herman Boerhaave]], Dutch humanist writer (born [[1668 in literature|1668]]) *[[November 10]] – [[John Asgill]], English pamphleteer (born [[1659 in literature|1659]])
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artefact | name = Broighter Hoard | image =[[File:Broighter Gold, Dublin, October 2010 (02).JPG|300px]] | image_caption =The boat, bowl, and part of the torc | material = [[Gold]] | created = | period = 1st century | discovered = 1896, near [[Limavady]], [[Northern Ireland]], by Tom Nicholl and James Morrow | location = [[National Museum of Ireland]] }} [[File:Broighter Gold, Dublin, October 2010 (03).JPG|thumb|right|The boat]] [[File:Broighter Torc design Evans 1897.jpg|thumb|220px|Torc design recorded by [[Arthur Evans]]]] [[File:Broighter Gold location- Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland, Fifth Series, Vol. 32, No. 3 (Sep. 30, 1902), pp. 211-224.jpg|thumb|right|The location of the find – the horizontally hashed areas show an area of reclaimed land which was previously part of [[Lough Foyle]].<ref name=cochrane>Cochrane, Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland, Fifth Series, Vol. 32, No. 3 (Sep. 30, 1902), pp. 211-224</ref>]] [[File:Broighter Torc The Journal of the Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland, Fifth Series, Vol. 32, No. 3 (Sep. 30, 1902), pp. 211-224 - Google Chrome-1.jpg|thumb|right|The torc and the bowl.<ref name=cochrane/>]] [[File:Boat Bits - Broighter Gold.jpg|thumb|right|The smaller parts that made up the model of the boat. 1. Boat hook 2. Mast yard 3. Steering oar 4. Small grappling iron 5. Forked implements 6. Square ended oars 7. oars.<ref name=cochrane/>]] The '''Broighter Gold''' or more correctly, the '''Broighter Hoard''', is a [[hoard]] of [[gold]] [[Artifact (archaeology)|artefacts]] from the [[Iron Age]] of the 1st century BC that were found in 1896 by Tom Nicholl and James Morrow on farmland near [[Limavady]], in the north of [[Ireland]] (now [[Northern Ireland]]).<ref name=ency/> The hoard includes a {{convert|7|in|cm|adj=mid|-long}} gold boat, a gold [[torc]] and bowl and some other jewellery. A design from the hoard has been used as an image on the 1996 issue of the [[Northern Ireland]] [[One pound (British coin)|British one-pound coins]]<ref name=ukpound/> and the gold ship featured in a design on the last [[Éire|Irish]] one-pound coins.<ref name=imint/> The Broighter Collar and Broighter Ship also featured on [[definitive postage stamps of Ireland]] from 1990–1995. The [[National Museum of Ireland]], who now hold the hoard, describe the torc as the "finest example of Irish [[La Tène]] goldworking".<ref name="muse"/> Replicas of the collection are kept at the [[Ulster Museum]] in [[Belfast]].
==Discovery== The hoard was found near [[Lough Foyle]] in a field in the [[townland]] of [[Broighter]] ({{Irish place name|Brú Íochtair|lower fort}})<ref>[http://www.logainm.ie/58017.aspx Broighter/Brú Íochtair] ''Placenames Database of Ireland''. Retrieved: 2011-05-31.</ref> 2 km northwest of [[Limavady]] in [[County Londonderry]]. It was discovered by Thomas Nicholl and James Morrow<ref name=lim>[http://www.limavady.gov.uk/visiting/myths-and-legends/ Myths and Legends], Limavady.gov.uk, accessed July 2010</ref> while working as ploughmen for Joseph L. Gibson in February 1896. They found the hoard whilst double ploughing. That means that one plough would follow the other to gain extra depth. It was estimated that the finds were buried {{convert|14|in|cm}} deep and were in close proximity to each other.
The find was taken to the farm where Maggie (later Mrs Nicholl) washed the items in a sink. At that time they did not realise they were made from gold.<ref name=neill>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/20558469?seq=2 The Broighter Hoard: Or How Carson Caught the Boat], Ken Neill, Archaeology Ireland, Vol. 7, No. 2 (Summer, 1993), pp. 24-26, accessed July 2010</ref> The hoard was eventually sold to the [[British Museum]] for six hundred pounds. It consisted of a miniature ship, complete with fittings and oars; two necklets, a bowl and a torc (or hollow collar).<ref name=ency>{{cite web|url=http://www.visual-arts-cork.com/irish-crafts/broighter-collar.htm |title=Broighter Collar |accessdate=24 July 2010 |work=Encyclopedia of Irish and World Art|publisher=visual-arts-cork.com}}</ref> The find was described as a lump of mud when initially shown. Moreover, the boat had been so badly damaged by the plough that it took a goldsmith to later work out its structure.
Part of the boat, a thwart, was found a few days later and sold by Morrow's sister to a jeweller in Londonderry.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/pss/20495224 The Broighter Boat a reassessment], A.W.Farrell et al, 1975, Irish Archaeological Research Forum, accessed July 2010</ref>
==The finds== The gold in the hoard all has the same metallurgical character, despite the diverse styles of the pieces. Some appear to be imported, while others may be reworked or entirely remade.<ref name="Wallace128-129">Wallace, 128-129</ref>
===The boat=== The boat is a unique find that was measured at {{convert|7.25|in|cm}} by {{convert|3|in|cm}} and weighed {{convert|3|oz|g}}. It had benches, rowlocks, two rows of nine oars and a paddle rudder for steering. It also included tools for grappling, three forks, a yardarm and a spear.<ref name=romilly>[https://books.google.com/books?id=z81vtIANeoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Romilly+Allen's+%22Celtic+Art%22&source=bl&ots=-cc8NgAIXy&sig=cnSOKFyHh792o2xMC2lO1u_ZZMc&hl=en&ei=4lRLTPjhKsiOjAew99nXDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Romilly%20Allen's%20%22Celtic%20Art%22&f=false Celtic Art in Pagan and Christian Times], J. Romilly Allen, 1904, p.104-5, accessed July 2010</ref> The tools are of much lighter design than the ship's hull and are shown in the illustration. The boat suggests that the hoard was a [[votive]] deposit to the Celtic sea god [[Manannán mac Lir]].<ref name="Wallace138">Wallace, 138</ref>
===The torc=== The other remarkable item was the [[torc]] or collar which is {{convert|7.5|in|cm}} in diameter with buffer terminals, using a [[mortice and tenon]] fastening. The hollow tube that made up the ring is {{convert|1.125|in|cm}} in diameter.<ref name=romilly/> The hinge is no longer there but it would have been required to put on the collar. The fastening consists of a "T" piece which fits into a slot as the torc is closed. A section can then be turned which captures the "T" and prevents it opening.<ref name="muse"/>
The design has been applied in three ways, the most common is where the classical designs of generic plants has been revealed by beating back the surrounding gold. Other areas have additional pieces attached and the background has been incised in geometric curves to add to the decoration.<ref name="muse">[http://www.museum.ie/en/exhibition/list/8-major-pieces.aspx?article=33b0a53d-0f90-49ca-a280-16260a062a04 The Broighter Hoard] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619010812/http://www.museum.ie/en/exhibition/list/8-major-pieces.aspx?article=33b0a53d-0f90-49ca-a280-16260a062a04 |date=19 June 2010 }}, [[National Museum of Ireland]], accessed July 2010</ref>
There are no comparable La Tène style hollow torcs known from Ireland, although somewhat similar examples such as the [[Snettisham Torc]] are known from Britain in this period. The design on the torc can be studied easily by imagining the hollow tube as straightened and flattened. This was done in the first study of the hoard by Arthur Evans and his drawing can be seen here. The design matches other Irish pieces, and may have been a remodelling of a plainer British or [[Rhineland]] torc (the Rhineland is one possible source of the gold).<ref name="Wallace128-129"/>
===Bowl=== An unusual gold bowl or model cauldron which was made from a single sheet of gold was discovered. Its purpose is unclear but it was probably a model of a large cauldron, which was an important object in the feasting culture of Iron Age Europe. It had four suspension loops on the outside, not all surviving.<ref name="Wallace138"/> It is {{convert|3.5|in|cm}} in diameter and is about {{convert|2|in|cm}} deep. It weighs over {{convert|1|oz|g}}.<ref name=cochrane/> [[Hanging bowl]]s were later to be a distinctive feature of post-Roman British and Irish art, often thought to be a speciality of Celtic areas.
===Chain necklaces=== There are two chain necklaces, using loop-in-loop technique, with clasps. One is 39.6 cm long, with triple chains, the other with a single chain but of more complicated construction. The chain technique spread from the Middle East to the Roman world, where these were probably made; the clasps match Roman and [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] examples.<ref name=muse/><ref name="Wallace139">Wallace, 139</ref>
===Bar torcs=== There are also two torcs made from single twisted bars of gold, a British style. One is complete, with a diameter of 18.6 cm, the other a semi-circular fragment. Despite unusual hook-in-loop fastenings and other features, these are probably imports from what is now south-eastern England.<ref name="Wallace139"/>
==Ownership== The hoard was sold by the farmer, J.L.Gibson, to a jeweller in [[Derry]] who sold it to a local [[antiquarian]], Robert Day. He sold it to the [[British Museum]] for £600. The museum had undisturbed ownership until the renowned [[Arthur Evans]] wrote a paper describing the find in 1897. The drawing of the torc design comes from this paper.<ref name=neill/> The [[Royal Irish Academy]] disputed the British Museum's view that it was an ancient gift to the gods and launched a long running court case. The Academy wanted the finds to be declared [[treasure trove]], that is, buried with the intention of recovery. Day, the antiquarian, was so aggrieved to have his sale disputed that he withdrew a gift he was going to make to the Irish Academy.
It was argued that the model of the boat and the "sea-horse image" on the torc when combined with the finding of nearby shells showed that the treasure had been placed in water deliberately as an offering to ancient gods. The map above shows how close the find was both to the sea and to reclaimed land where the railway then travelled. The British Museum's position was set out by Evans who had described the find as ''[[votive]]'' in his 1897 paper – ironically something the Academy's successor, the National Museum of Ireland, now consider likely, saying on their website: "The objects may have been buried as an offering to a Celtic god, presumably during the first Century BC".<ref name="muse"/>
The dispute was finally settled by a court in London in 1903 in an important case where the government was represented by [[Edward Carson|Sir Edward Carson]], who was a [[Unionism in Ireland|Unionist]] and [[Solicitor General for England and Wales|Solicitor-General]].<ref name=neill/> A pivotal issue in the case were that the finds were all closely packed which was indicative of burial. It was held that the treasure was not a religious offering and was therefore forfeit to the crown.<ref name="ency"/> The treasure was taken to Dublin and placed in the museum there. Although some{{who|date=December 2016}} have suggested that the gold should be transferred to nearer their find-spot in what is now [[Northern Ireland]], the items remain in the National Museum of Ireland in Dublin.
==Importance== The hoard is considered an important find. The [[National Museum of Ireland]] believes that the collar is the "finest example of Irish [[La Tène]] goldworking" in Europe. The eclecticism of the styles is comparable to that of the objects in the [[Stirling Hoard]] from Scotland, probably from a slightly earlier period. The torc was incorporated into a 1996 design for a British pound by [[Norman Sillman]]<ref name=ukpound>[http://www.royalmint.com/store/Historic/HPT96P.aspx 1996 Silver Piedfort £1 - Northern Irish Celtic Cross] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106224906/http://www.royalmint.com/store/Historic/HPT96P.aspx |date=6 January 2011 }}, The Royal Mint, accessed 28 July 2010</ref> and the boat was used as a basis for the design for the last pound coin ever issued by the [[Irish Mint]].<ref name=imint>[http://www.irishcoinage.com/K00001.HTM Millennium Pound - Silver Piedfort Proof], irishcoinage.com, accessed 28 July 2010</ref> This coin was issued to celebrate the millennium in 2000.
==See also== *[[List of hoards in Ireland]] * [[Caergwrle]], Wales, for the Caergwrle Bowl, apparently a miniature boat in [[slate]] with gold * [[Ardagh Hoard]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Wallace, Patrick F., O'Floinn, Raghnall (eds.) (2002), ''Treasures of the National Museum of Ireland: Irish Antiquities'', [[Gill & Macmillan]], Dublin, {{ISBN|0-7171-2829-6}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/op1254090-1001 |title=Summary of facts and correspondence with respect to Celtic Ornaments found in 1896 at Limavady in north west of Ireland |accessdate=10 September 2016 |series=[[Command paper]]s |volume=Cd.241 |date=1900 |publisher=[[HMSO]] |location=London }}
==External links== {{Commons category|Broighter Gold}} *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/113771/rec/1 Treasures of early Irish art, 1500 B.C. to 1500 A.D.], an exhibition catalogue from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on the Broighter Gold (cat. no. 21) *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/yourplaceandmine/londonderry/broighter_gold_simpson.htm Photo of Tom Nicholl] {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}
[[Category:Treasure troves in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in County Londonderry]] [[Category:Collection of the National Museum of Ireland]] [[Category:Celtic art]] [[Category:Torcs]] [[Category:1896 archaeological discoveries]] [[Category:1896 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1896 in Ireland]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Use British English|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Carcass | image = Carcass_in_Wolverhampton,_October_2015.jpg | caption = Carcass in Wolverhampton, October 2015 | image_size = | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Liverpool, England]], United Kingdom | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Death metal]] * {{nowrap|[[melodic death metal]]}} * [[grindcore]] (early) }} | years_active = {{flatlist| * 1985–1996 * 2007–present}} | label = {{flatlist| * [[Earache Records|Earache]] * [[Nuclear Blast]] * [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]/[[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony]] * [[Combat Records|Combat]] * [[Relativity Records|Relativity]]}} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Arch Enemy]] * [[Firebird (band)|Firebird]] * [[Blackstar (band)|Blackstar]] * [[Brujeria (band)|Brujeria]] * [[Napalm Death]] }} | website = | current_members = [[Bill Steer]]
[[Jeffrey Walker|Jeff Walker]]
[[Daniel Wilding]]
Tom Draper | past_members = [[Michael Amott]]
Sanjiv
Mike Hickey
Carlo Regadas
[[Ken Owen]]
[[Daniel Erlandsson]]
Ben Ash }} '''Carcass''' are an English [[extreme metal]] band from Liverpool, which was formed in 1985. The band have gone through several line-up changes, leaving guitarist [[Bill Steer]] and bassist and vocalist [[Jeffrey Walker|Jeff Walker]] as the only constant members. They broke up in 1996,{{cite news|url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/carcass_jeff_walker|title=Carcass' Jeff Walker|website=Exclaim.ca|date=27 August 2008|accessdate=9 January 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://theageofmetal.com/bill-steer-of-carcass-chats-with-the-age-of-metal/|title=Bill Steer of Carcass chats with The Age of Metal|website=Theageofmetal.com|date=28 August 2013|accessdate=9 January 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1477402/qa-carcass-on-surgical-steel-the-pitfalls-of-legacy-and-first-aid-kits/franchises/interview/|title=Q&A: Carcass On Surgical Steel, The Pitfalls Of Legacy, And First Aid Kits|website=Stereogum.com|date=17 September 2013|accessdate=9 January 2017}} but reformed in 2007 without one of its original members, drummer [[Ken Owen]], due to health reasons.{{cite news|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/reunited-carcass-confirmed-for-next-year-s-wacken-open-air-festival/|title=Reunited Carcass confirmed for next year's Wacken Open Air|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=6 October 2007|accessdate=6 October 2007}} To date, the band have released six studio albums, two compilation albums, four EPs, two demo albums, one video album, and six music videos. Carcass are regarded as pioneers of the [[goregrind]] genre.{{cite journal | last = Widener | first = Matthew | title = Carcass Clones | journal = Decibel Magazine | url = http://www.decibelmagazine.com/features/dec2005/carcass_clones.aspx | accessdate = 27 February 2009 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080116115258/http://www.decibelmagazine.com/features/dec2005/carcass_clones.aspx | archivedate = 16 January 2008}} Their early work was also tagged as "splatter death metal",{{cite journal |last=Filho |first=Fernando Souza |title=Os novos rumos do Death Metal |url= |date=1993 |journal=Rock Brigade |publisher= |volume=12 |issue=85 |page=56 |doi=}} and "hardgore"{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Carcass: Symphonies of Sickness |url= |date=1991 |journal=[[Spin Magazine]] |publisher= |volume=7 |issue=3 |page=62 |doi=}} on account of their morbid lyrics and gruesome album covers. They also became one of the pioneers of [[melodic death metal]] with their 1993 album ''[[Heartwork]]''.{{cite web|last=Norton|first=Justin|title=Carcass Profile|url=http://heavymetal.about.com/od/carcass/p/carcass.htm|publisher=[[About.com]]|accessdate=23 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707075151/http://heavymetal.about.com/od/carcass/p/carcass.htm|archivedate=7 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} The band's lyrics often focus on animal rights issues. Walker and Steer are both [[vegetarian]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.metalinjection.net/lists/10-vegan-vegetarian-metal-bands/3|title=10 Vegan/Vegetarian Metal Bands That Skip The Turkey on Thanksgiving - Page 3 of 3 - Metal Injection|date=26 November 2014|website=Metalinjection.net|accessdate=18 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.invisibleoranges.com/interview-jeff-walker-of-carcass/|title=Interview: Jeff Walker of Carcass|website=Invisible Oranges - The Metal Blog|accessdate=18 January 2018}} Steer used to be [[vegan]] and Walker was a [[Hunt sabotage|hunt saboteur]].{{cite web|url=http://hellbound.ca/2014/04/carcass/|title=Still going down well: interview with Carcass guitarist Bill Steer |website=Hellbound.ca|date=7 April 2014|accessdate=18 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.collideartandculture.com/single-post/2015/04/08/Interview-Bill-Steer-of-Carcass|title=Collide Art & Culture Mag|website=Collide Art & Culture Mag|accessdate=18 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.metalstorm.net/bands/bandmember.php?member_id=1368|title=Jeffrey "Jeff" Walker - Metal Storm|website=Metalstorm.net|accessdate=18 January 2018}} {{TOClimit|3}} ==History== ===Early days (1985–1989)=== [[Image:Carcass 30.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Jeff Walker at Gods of Metal, Bologna, Italy (2008)]] Carcass was first formed as a school band by Bill Steer and Ken Owen that soon after disbanded.{{Cite web|url=http://www.collideartandculture.com/#!Interview-Bill-Steer-of-Carcass/c1lt4/55251a980cf215f35a4bc3c2|title=Interview: Bill Steer of Carcass|last=Lennon|first=Andi|date=8 April 2015|website=Collide Art & Culture Mag|access-date=2016-03-03}} Steer then joined the [[D-beat]] band Disattack with drummer Middie, Paul on bass and Pek on vocals.{{Cite web|url = http://www.stereogum.com/1424501/premature-evaluation-carcass-surgical-steel/franchises/premature-evaluation/|title = Premature Evaluation: Carcass Surgical Steel|last = Nelson|first = Michael|date = 2 August 2013|website = Stereogum|access-date = 2016-03-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://toughriffs.weebly.com/interviews/interview-with-carlo-regadas-devoid|title=Interview with Carlo Regadas, Devoid|website=Tough Riffs
Magazine|access-date=2016-03-03}} After releasing a four track demo entitled ''A Bomb Drops ...'' in 1986,{{Cite web|url=http://demoarchives.com/Bands/Disattack-Eng/disattack.asp|title=Disattack - The Bomb Drops demo listing.|website=demoarchives.com|access-date=2016-03-03}} the bass player left the band and was replaced by [[Jeffrey Walker|Jeff Walker]], formerly guitarist and vocalist of the [[Electro Hippies]]. Vocalist Andrew Pek changed his name to Sanjiv after a visit to India. At about the same time, Bill Steer joined [[Napalm Death]] (replacing [[Justin Broadrick]]) and recorded the second side of what became Napalm Death's first album, ''[[Scum (Napalm Death album)|Scum]]''. Walker also designed the cover art for ''Scum''. Disattack then changed its name to Carcass as the group changed musical direction. This led to a change in drummer and saw Ken Owen join the band.{{Cite web|url=https://www.earache.com/bands/carcass/news_archive/carcass.html|title=Carcass: The First Interview in Five Years|date=30 May 2005|website=earache.com|access-date=2016-03-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923232451/http://www.earache.com/bands/carcass/news_archive/carcass.html#|archive-date=23 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In April 1987, they recorded the ''Flesh Ripping Sonic Torment'' demo, the only Carcass recording featuring vocalist Sanjiv, who left shortly after. Walker, Steer and Owen shared vocal duties for the debut album, which was done in only four days. Despite the primitive production values of Carcass's debut ''[[Reek of Putrefaction]]'' (1988), with which the band was very displeased,{{cite web|url=http://www.goddamnbastard.org/carcass/interviews/rockhard40.html|title=Carcass - Perverted Sickos|date=June 1990|publisher=Rock Hard|accessdate=30 April 2008}} it became a favourite of [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] DJ [[John Peel]].{{cite book |last=Mudrian |first=Albert |authorlink= |title=[[Choosing Death: The Improbable History of Death Metal and Grindcore]] |url= |accessdate= |year=2004 |publisher=Feral House |location=Los Angeles, CA |isbn= |page=132}} Due to his interest, they were asked to participate in their first [[List of Peel sessions#C|Peel Session]] in 1989, where they debuted new material for their second album. The Peel Session was released as an EP with the band members adopting [[pseudonyms]]: K. Grumegargler, J. Offalmangler, and W.G. Thorax Embalmer. Also that year, Steer and Walker appeared as members of Lister's fictional band ''Smeg and the Heads'' in an episode of [[Red Dwarf]].Carcass - The Pathologist's Report documentary ===Progress (1989–1993)=== [[Image:Bill Steer.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Bill Steer at Gods of Metal, Bologna, Italy (2008)]] ''[[Symphonies of Sickness]]'' (1989), the second album, which contained a much improved production quality (courtesy of Colin Richardson), featured more [[death metal]] structures and longer songs with more slow passages.{{cite book|last=J. Purcell|first=Natalie|title=Death Metal Music: The Passion and Politics of a Subculture|date=5 May 2003|isbn=0-7864-1585-1|pages=21–22|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AwJJR5vvlIsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Choosing+Death:+The+Improbable+History+of+Death+Metal+%26+Grindcore+Carcass&hl=es&source=gbs_book_similarbooks#v=onepage&q&f=false|editor=McFarland|accessdate=18 December 2011|quote=Carcass' following album, ''Symphonies of Sickness'', featured slower and catchier songs, and showed the band's movement into the Death Metal genre. The next album, ''Necroticism: Descanting the Insalubrious'', was pure Death Metal with intricate dynamics, complex structured songs, and refined guitar solos.}} The second half of the tour in support of ''Symphonies of Sickness'' saw the addition of second lead guitarist [[Michael Amott]], whose previous work included [[Carnage (band)|Carnage]]. Amott was to become a permanent member, playing on the second Peel Session and contributing material towards their third album. ''[[Necroticism – Descanting the Insalubrious]]'' (1991) showed even more intricate composition, further improved production and guitar solos. Despite the addition of Amott to the ranks, Steer still handled all rhythm guitar duties, with Amott only contributing leads and one riff.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-giving-people-what-they-want/|title=Carcass Giving People What They Want|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=18 September 2013|accessdate=18 October 2013}} Carcass again supported the album with heavy touring, and were part of the Earache 'Gods of Grind' tour with [[Cathedral (band)|Cathedral]], [[Entombed (band)|Entombed]] and [[Confessor (band)|Confessor]] in both Europe and the United States. The ''[[Tools of the Trade]]'' EP was released in 1992 to coincide with the "Gods of Grind" tour. ===Columbia (1993–1995)=== [[Image:Michael Ammot.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Michael Amott at Gods of Metal, Bologna, Italy (2008)]] The band's fourth album, ''[[Heartwork]]'', was released in late 1993. It was considered a radical change by many fans,{{cite web|last=Franklin|first=Dan|title=Can You Feel The Forceps: Carcass, Surgical Steel And Heartwork Revisited|url=http://thequietus.com/articles/13361-carcass-surgical-steel-review|publisher=[[The Quietus]]|accessdate=19 October 2013|date=16 September 2013}} which eliminated Steer's deeper vocals and the clinically gory lyrics. Again, Steer handled all rhythm guitar duties, this time due to Amott losing his passport in Israel (thus making him unable to return to England in time to record). Song structures, whilst still containing musically complex parts, were simpler, in some cases using the verse/chorus/verse formula. After the release of ''Heartwork'', Carcass signed a worldwide deal with [[Columbia Records]], who hoped for commercial success, even suggesting that Jeff Walker learn how to sing. Michael Amott left the band right after ''Heartwork'' was recorded, and was for a while replaced by Mike Hickey, who was later replaced by Carlo Regadas. During the summer of 1994, Walker remixed the track "Inside Out" for a [[Die Krupps]] remix album, although the version stayed fairly true to the original with the exception of Owen's drum samples from ''Heartwork'' replacing the Die Krupps original, and additional mixing from Walker and Colin Richardson at Parr Street studios (where ''Heartwork'' was recorded).{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} Carcass now set about writing songs for their major label debut. During the December 1994 UK tour Carcass showcased two songs from their current writing sessions – "Edge of Darkness" and "Firmhand", both showing a more straight forward song writing approach than on previous efforts.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} Around this time, "Edge of Darkness" was recorded for the BBC Radio 1 Rock Show sessions – a session which could be found on later compilation albums.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} By late 1994, 17 songs were ready and the band set about using their $200,000 advance to record the album, again with Colin Richardson, at Rockfield studios in Monmouth, South Wales in early 1995. During the 6-week recording schedule the record label began to withdraw support, stating that Carcass were not ready to record, and needed to write more songs. This advice was ignored, as was the suggestion to have [[Terry Date]] remix the album, and the band continued. At the time, Jeff Walker stated in an interview with the UK's Metal Hammer Magazine that the album was taking more of a classic rock approach, with drums, bass and twin guitars à la Thin Lizzy, in comparison to earlier "multi-layered guitar" productions. This has since been put down to Bill Steer's unwillingness to perform the time consuming guitar layering (as once again Steer performed all rhythm guitar) through losing interest in the metal genre. During the ''Swansong'' recording sessions, Carcass were asked to remix a [[Björk]] track - "[[Isobel (song)|Isobel]]". This wasn't a remix as such but more of a re-recording with only Björk's vocals remaining. The track saw the light of day in March 1996 on Björk's "[[Hyperballad]]" single. ===Demise (1996–2006)=== Continuing record company problems with Columbia/Sony caused the album to be delayed from late summer 1995 to June 1996, in which time Carcass moved back to Earache Records, and broke up before even releasing ''[[Swansong (album)|Swansong]]''. The move back to Earache was dubbed by Walker as "the second great rock and roll swindle"''[[Kerrang!]]'', June 1996 as they had effectively been paid twice for the same album. ''Swansong'' featured twelve of the seventeen tracks put to tape during the recording sessions. Walker has since stated in interviews that all seventeen songs should have been included in a double album, and that some songs omitted from ''Swansong'' were actually stronger than some of ''Swansong''{{'}}s actual content. Carcass also remixed [[Killing Joke]]'s "Democracy" (by re-recording the music, but keeping the original vocals), although this time Regadas performed all guitar duties, as it is thought Steer had quit the band by early 1996. The Carcass "Rooster Mix" was made available on Killing Joke's ''[[Democracy (album)|Democracy]]''. Around the time of ''Swansong'''s release, Carcass informed the press that they were ending the band without even a farewell tour, but most fans had guessed this may be the case via the album title. The album sold well, staying near the top of the Indie Rock Chart in the UK for several months, above bands such as [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]], despite having no touring support from the band. It is rumoured that the band were offered several lucrative tours in 1995, such as supporting [[Iron Maiden]] on their "X-Factour 95" tour, which had the album been released as expected in 1995, could have improved the band's sales and longevity. A posthumous compilation, ''[[Wake up and Smell the... Carcass]]'' was released in October 1996 to collect together Carcass' rarer material, including unreleased material, songs only available on EPs and compilations, and live tracks. An accompanying video was released a few weeks after the ''Wake Up'' CD with little knowledge from the band or their management. The video, later released on DVD, featured five of the band's promotional videos, a show from the Grindcrusher 1989 tour (as a three piece) and a show from the 1992 Gods of Grind tour. Sound on the two live shows is poor, particularly the latter, which Walker has described as "unmixed". Owen, Walker, and Regadas continued with the band [[Blackstar (band)|Blackstar]], accompanied by former [[Cathedral (band)|Cathedral]] bassist Mark Griffiths, using the second ''Swansong'' advance from Earache to fund the recording. Blackstar, later Blackstar Rising, became defunct after drummer Owen suffered a severe [[cerebral hemorrhage]]. Amott went on to found [[hard rock]] band [[Spiritual Beggars]] and successful Swedish melodic death metal band [[Arch Enemy (band)|Arch Enemy]]. In the biggest musical departure, Steer formed [[Firebird (band)|Firebird]], a [[Eric Clapton|Clapton]]-esque rock band. ===Reformation (2007–2012)=== In June 2006, in an interview with Walker, he discussed the possibility of reforming Carcass, but mentioned that it was unlikely that Owen would participate, since he could not replicate his former drumming proficiency due to the effects of the cerebral hemorrhage he suffered in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.lordsofmetal.nl/showinterview.php?id=1376&lang=en|title=Archive|publisher=Lordsofmetal.nl|accessdate=30 January 2011}} In September 2007, Michael Amott announced that he was rehearsing with Bill Steer, Jeff Walker and [[Daniel Erlandsson]] (replacing Ken Owen) in secret to rehearse old Carcass songs for a possible reunion tour. The original plans were to play at several festivals during the summer, but they couldn't meet the deadlines.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/mike-amott-carcass-has-rehearsed-and-may-reunite-for-tour/|title=MIKE AMOTT: CARCASS Has Rehearsed And May Reunite For Tour|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=18 September 2007|accessdate=18 October 2013}} In October 2007, Carcass were confirmed to play at German heavy metal festival [[Wacken Open Air]] and Finland's [[Tuska Open Air Metal Festival]] in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.wacken.com/en/woa2010/main-news/news/archiv/archiv-single/article/sensation-carcass-is-back/|title=Sensation : CARCASS is back!!|website=Wacken.com|accessdate=30 January 2011}} Carcass later embarked on a reunion tour, beginning on 6 June 2008 at the Sweden Rock Festival in Norje, Sweden. Carcass also played at [[Hellfest Summer Open Air]], [[Metalcamp]] and several other festivals. The band toured Australia and New Zealand in 2008, and then in North America during September and October 2008, followed by the band's first South American tour, playing in Colombia, Chile, Argentina and Brazil. On 15 November 2008, Carcass headlined the Danish Metal Awards held in Amager Bio, Copenhagen, Denmark. Steer also presented the award for Best Danish Debut Album, which went to SCAMP for ''Mirror Faced Mentality''. Carcass surprised the audience by bringing Ken Owen to the stage where he gave a brief drum solo to show how far he had come in recovering from his illness. Carcass performed an exclusive UK show at the [[Damnation Festival]] in Leeds. It was the first time Carcass had played in England in 14 years. Carcass re-released their entire back catalogue with bonus material during 2008 on [[Earache Records]].{{cite web|url=http://askearache.blogspot.com/2008/03/carcass-5-dvd-documentaries-coming-up.html|title=ASK EARACHE: CARCASS- 5 DVD documentaries coming up soon|website=Askearache.blogspot.com|accessdate=30 January 2011}} When asked if the band were planning on writing and recording a new album, Steer replied: {{quote|I would be very surprised if that would really happen. But never say never, I'm always the last one who needs to be convinced. Michael and Jeff are much more busy with those things than I am. I'm also not very much involved in the planning of all the festivals which are scheduled. At this moment, I barely know in which countries we're all going to play.|Bill Steer|''Voices from the Dark Side''{{cite web | title=Interview with Bill Steer | publisher=Voices from the Dark Side | url=http://www.voicesfromthedarkside.de/Interviews/CARCASS--6859.html | accessdate=4 August 2008}}}} Carcass continued to play live in 2009, with a North American tour completed in March 2009. Carcass also headlined the [[Bloodstock Open Air]] in Derbyshire, England in August 2009. In August 2010, Carcass headlined [[Vagos Open Air]] in [[Vagos Municipality|Vagos]], Portugal,{{cite web|url=http://www.vagosopenair.eu/|title=Names Confirmed|publisher=Vagos Openair|accessdate=30 January 2011}} and [[Jalometalli Metal Music Festival]] held in [[Oulu]], Finland.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/suffocation-gorgoroth-dream-evil-confirmed-for-finland-s-jalometalli-festival/|title=SUFFOCATION, GORGOROTH, DREAM EVIL Confirmed For Finland's JALOMETALLI Festival|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=18 February 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}} At Hellfest 2010, they performed the ''Necroticism'' album in its entirety.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} In 2012, Amott and Erlandsson left Carcass to focus on Arch Enemy.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/reactivated-carcass-taps-trigger-the-bloodshed-drummer-for-comeback-album/ |title=Reactivated CARCASS Taps TRIGGER THE BLOODSHED Drummer For Comeback Album |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date= 12 December 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2013}} ===''Surgical Steel'' (2012–present)=== Steer and Walker started talking about recording a new album after the reunion shows were done. They wrote some songs to see how they would turn out. According to Steer, "If it sounded like Carcass to us, we were going to proceed. We also said if it didn't feel right, we'd just drop it".{{cite web|last=Bowar|first=Chad|title=Carcass Guitarist Bill Steer on Comeback Album Surgical Steel - "It's Not Really Cool If You're Influenced By Yourself"|url=http://www.bravewords.com/news/211956|publisher=[[Brave Words & Bloody Knuckles]]|accessdate=19 October 2013|date=13 October 2013}} Carcass recorded a new album in 2012, titled ''[[Surgical Steel (album)|Surgical Steel]]''. [[Daniel Wilding]] of [[Bristol]]-based [[deathgrind]] band [[Trigger the Bloodshed]] performs drums on ''Surgical Steel''.{{cite web|url=http://www.decibelmagazine.com/featured/decibel-exclusive-jeff-walker-speaks-about-the-new-carcass-record|title=Decibel Exclusive: Jeff Walker Speaks About the New Carcass Record!}} The original drummer, Ken Owen, was also brought in to record some backing vocals on the album.{{cite web|title=Thrash Hits TV: Carcass discuss having Ken Owen on backing vocals for Surgical Steel|url=http://www.thrashhits.com/2013/09/thrash-hits-tv-carcass-discuss-having-ken-owen-on-backing-vocals-for-surgical-steel/|publisher=Thrash Hits|accessdate=18 October 2013}} Ben Ash of Pig Iron, Desolation, and Liquefied Skeleton joined the band in March 2013 on guitar.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/new-carcass-lineup-performs-live-for-first-time-video-footage-available/ |title=New CARCASS Lineup Performs Live For First Time; Video Footage Available |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=6 August 2013}} On 26 March 2013 Carcass performed for the first time with their new lineup at the [[Camden Underworld]] in London, where they played for three nights.{{cite web|last=Shaw|first=Zach|title=Carcass Performs First Show With New Lineup, Give More Insight into Why Colin Richardson Quit|url=http://www.metalinsider.net/video/carcass-performs-first-show-with-new-lineup-give-more-insight-into-why-colin-richardson-quit|publisher=Metal Insider|accessdate=18 October 2013}} Carcass also performed at the Chilean music festival Metalfest in April 2013,{{cite web |url=http://www.themetalfest.cl/noticia/carcass-confirmado-para-the-metal-fest-2013/ |title=THE METAL FEST 2013 |website=Themetalfest.cl |date= |accessdate=14 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216053030/http://www.themetalfest.cl/noticia/carcass-confirmado-para-the-metal-fest-2013/# |archive-date=16 February 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} and the [[Maryland Deathfest|Maryland Deathfest XI]] music festival in May 2013.{{cite web|last=Rosenberg |first=Axl |url=http://www.metalsucks.net/2012/07/20/next-years-maryland-deathfest-already-looks-great/#more-98122 |title=Next Year's Maryland Deathfest Already Looks Great |publisher=MetalSucks |date= |accessdate=14 February 2013}} In May 2013 Carcass signed with [[Nuclear Blast]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-signs-with-nuclear-blast-records/ |title=Carcass Signs With Nuclear Blast Records |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=6 August 2013}} In Japan they signed a deal with Trooper Entertainment for the release of the new album.{{cite web|title=Carcass Signs Japanese Deal With Trooper Entertainment|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-signs-japanese-deal-with-trooper-entertainment/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=6 June 2013|accessdate=18 October 2013}} Carcass released ''Surgical Steel'' on 13 September 2013 in Europe, 16 September in the UK, and 17 September in North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-walker-steer-explain-their-choice-of-new-touring-members/|title=Carcass' Walker, Steer Explain Their Choice of New Touring Members|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=12 September 2013|accessdate=13 September 2013}} Overall the album received positive reviews. ''Surgical Steel'' earned a Top 50 position on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] charts.{{cite web|title=CARCASS: 'Surgical Steel' Cracks U.S. Top 50|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-surgical-steel-cracks-u-s-top-50/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=25 September 2013|accessdate=18 October 2013}} After releasing ''Surgical Steel'', Carcass headlined [[Damnation Festival]] in Leeds before embarking on the Defenders of the Faith Tour with [[Amon Amarth]] and [[Hell (band)|Hell]], which ran throughout Europe and the UK in November and December 2013.{{cite web|title=CARCASS on Touring With AMON AMARTH - "Lock Up Your Dead Grandmothers"|url=http://www.bravewords.com/news/207338|website=Bravewords.com|accessdate=18 October 2013}} Carcass performed at [[70000 Tons of Metal]] in January 2014{{cite web |url=http://www.70000tons.com/artists.php |title=LINE UP 2015 | 70000TONS OF METAL - The World's Biggest Heavy Metal Cruise |website=70000tons.com |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2014-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209024102/http://70000tons.com/artists.php |archivedate=9 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }} and headlined the [[Agglutination Festival]] on 23 August of the same year.{{cite web|url=http://www.agglutination.it/main/?p=222|title=XX Edizione con CARCASS headliner's !!|website=Agglutination.it|date=|accessdate=2014-08-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716222957/http://www.agglutination.it/main/?p=222#|archive-date=16 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In a June 2014 interview with Metal Underground, Walker was asked if Carcass were going to make a follow-up to ''Surgical Steel''. He replied, "Ultimately, as long as we feel we got somewhere to go then we would create new material. We are not just going to do it just for the sake of it. We have to feel inspired. All I can say is I do see somewhere where we can take Carcass if we choose to do another album and personally I do want to do another album. I'm not completely satisfied with any album we've made so far. I don't think we've made the classic Carcass album, that's the way I feel."{{cite web|title=Interview With Carcass' Jeff Walker|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=103850|publisher=Metal Underground|date=22 June 2014|accessdate=20 July 2014}} Carcass released an EP titled ''[[Surgical Remission/Surplus Steel]]'' in November 2014. The EP is a collection of unreleased tracks recorded during the ''Surgical Steel'' sessions and it is released on physical and digital formats. "Well, let's call this tying up loose ends," commented Carcass frontman Jeff Walker. "We thought we'd make all the tracks available from the ''Surgical Steel'' album session on an EP… just in case you bought the jewel case version, didn't buy the digipak, didn't buy the Japanese import, or maybe you never bought the [[Decibel (magazine)|Decibel magazine]] issue with the flexi disc? Well, here you go; ALL the songs on one disc along with a previously unreleased track. Even [[The Black Dahlia Murder (band)|Trevor Strnad's]] arm makes a guest appearance! Enjoy."{{cite web|title=CARCASS To Release 'Surgical Remission / Surplus Steel' EP|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-to-release-surgical-remission-surplus-steel-ep/|publisher=Blabbermouth|accessdate=6 November 2014}} Carcass continued touring. They played at [[Download Festival]] in [[Castle Donington]] 13 June 2015. Reviewing their concert, James Weaver wrote: "Carcass have proved, not only that they can play any spectrum of rock festivals, but that they still remain as one of the greats in the extreme metal genre."{{cite web|last1=Weaver|first1=James|title=Download Festival 2015 Saturday Review: Hysteria|url=http://www.rocksins.com/2015/07/download-festival-2015-saturday-review-hysteria-25040/|website=Rock Sins|accessdate=7 January 2016}} Carcass also headlined the "Deathcrusher 2015" tour alongside [[Napalm Death]], [[Obituary (band)|Obituary]], [[Voivod (band)|Voivod]] and [[Herod (band)|Herod]]. The tour run in Europe October-November 2015.{{cite web|title=Carcass To Join Forces With Napalm Death, Obituary, Voivod For 'Deathcrusher' European Tour|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/carcass-to-join-forces-with-napalm-death-obituary-voivod-for-deathcrusher-european-tour/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=7 January 2016|date=June 30, 2015}} During the "Deathcrusher 2015" tour [[Bill Steer]] rejoined his former band [[Napalm Death]] on some dates to perform the classic Napalm Death song "Deceiver".{{cite web|title=Video: Carcass's Bill Steer Rejoins Napalm Death On Stage In Stockholm|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/video-carcasss-bill-steer-rejoins-napalm-death-on-stage-in-stockholm/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=7 January 2016|date=November 12, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Video: Carcass's Bill Steer Rejoins Napalm Death On Stage In Paris|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/video-carcasss-bill-steer-rejoins-napalm-death-on-stage-in-paris/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=7 January 2016|date=November 23, 2015}} Along with [[Testament (band)|Testament]], Carcass supported [[Slayer]] on their ''[[Repentless]]'' tour, which took place in February and March 2016.{{cite web|title=Slayer, Testament, Carcass: North American Tour Dates Officially Announced|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/slayer-testament-carcass-north-american-tour-dates-officially-announced/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=December 3, 2015|accessdate=December 3, 2015}} In a statement released in early March 2018, Ben Ash announced he had left Carcass. Tom Draper (Pounder, ex-[[Angel Witch]]), a UK native based in California, made his first live appearance with the band at the [[Maryland_Deathfest#Related_Events|Netherlands Deathfest]] on March 2, 2018, and his second appearance during the [[Decibel Magazine|Decibel]] Metal and Beer Fest in Philadelphia on April 1, 2018.{{cite web|last=|first=|title=CARCASS Guitarist BEN ASH Leaves Band; TOM DRAPER Steps In|url=http://bravewords.com/news/carcass-guitarist-ben-ash-leaves-band-tom-draper-steps-in|publisher=Brave Words|accessdate=2 April 2018}} They will also open for [[Slayer]] on selected dates of their [[Slayer Farewell Tour|final world tour]], including ForceFest in Mexico in October 2018,{{cite web|title=ASESINO To Celebrate DINO CAZARES's 52nd Birthday At Los Angeles Concert; Mexican Festival Appearance Announced|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/asesino-to-celebrate-dino-cazaress-52nd-birthday-at-los-angeles-concert-mexican-festival-appearance-announced/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=July 6, 2018|accessdate=September 28, 2018}}{{cite web|title=ForceFest 2018 lineup announced|url=https://lambgoat.com/news/30365/ForceFest-2018-lineup-announced|work=lambgoat.com|date=August 4, 2018|accessdate=September 28, 2018}} and [[Hellfest (French music festival)|Hellfest]] in France in June 2019.{{cite web|title=SLAYER To Play 'Last French Show Ever' At Next Year's HELLFEST|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/slayer-to-play-last-french-show-ever-at-next-years-hellfest/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=June 25, 2018|accessdate=September 28, 2018}} ==Influence and in popular culture== Carcass are influenced by death metal and grindcore bands like [[Death (metal band)|Death]], [[Repulsion (band)|Repulsion]], [[Master (American band)|Master]], [[Morbid Angel]], [[Napalm Death]], [[Macabre (band)|Macabre]], and other acts such as [[Slayer]], [[King Diamond (band)|King Diamond]], [[Cryptic Slaughter]], [[Discharge (band)|Discharge]], [[Siege (band)|Siege]], [[Straight Ahead (band)|N.Y.C. Mayhem]] and [[Diamond Head (band)|Diamond Head]].{{cite web |title=Interview with Jeff Walker |url=http://www.goddamnbastard.org/carcass/interviews/mindrot.html |accessdate=28 July 2018}}{{cite web|last=Gamble|first=Billy|title=Interview: Carcass’ Bill Steer|url=http://digboston.com/boston-music-concerts/2014/04/interview-carcass-bill-steer/|website=Digboston.com|date=7 April 2014|accessdate=17 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712164922/http://digboston.com/boston-music-concerts/2014/04/interview-carcass-bill-steer/|archivedate=12 July 2014|df=dmy-all}} Otrebor of black metal band [[Botanist (band)|Botanist]] cites Carcass' use of medical dictionary terms in lyrics and song titles as a precedent for its lyrics and song titles from plant and insect dictionaries.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2011/09/02/140122676/botanist-one-man-hammered-dulcimer-black-metal-no-really|title=Botanist: One-Man, Hammered-Dulcimer Black Metal (No, Really)|website=Npr.org|accessdate=18 January 2018}} On the ''[[Elementary (TV series)|Elementary]]'' episode "Bella", the song "Captive Bolt Pistol" is played on a mixtape that supposedly also contains a computer virus. In the ''[[Red Dwarf]]'' episode "[[Timeslides]]", Steer and Walker appeared as members of Lister's childhood band, ''Smeg and the Heads''.{{cite web|url=http://www.westword.com/music/carcass-bassist-jeff-walker-every-bass-player-is-just-a-failed-guitar-player-5684861|title=Carcass bassist Jeff Walker: "Every bass player is just a failed guitar player." |website=Westword.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}} ==Band members== ===Current=== * [[Bill Steer]] – guitars, backing vocals (1985–1996, 2007–present) * [[Jeffrey Walker|Jeff Walker]] – lead vocals, bass (1985–1996, 2007–present) * [[Daniel Wilding]] – drums (2012–present) * Tom Draper - guitars (2018-present) ===Past=== * Sanjiv Sumner – lead vocals (1986–1987) * Carlo Regadas – guitars (1994-1996) * [[Ken Owen]] – drums (1986–1996), backing vocals (1985-1996, guest vocals on ''Surgical Steel'', 2013, live guest 2008, 2009, 2010, 2013) * [[Michael Amott]] – guitars (1990–1993, 2007–2012) * [[Daniel Erlandsson]] – drums (2007–2012) * Ben Ash – guitars (2013–2018) ===Live musicians=== * Mike Hickey – guitars (1993–1994) ===Timeline=== ImageSize = width:800 height:auto '''Columbia Artists Management, Inc.''' ('''CAMI''') is an international talent management [[talent agent|agency]].
==History== Based in [[New York City]], it was formed in 1930 as Columbia Concerts Corporation by [[Arthur Judson]] and [[William S. Paley]], the then head of the [[Columbia Broadcasting System]], who helped merge seven independent concert bureaus in the United States.
During its existence, CAMI has represented a very large number of active classical artists worldwide, including singers [[Leontyne Price]], [[Elisabeth Schwarzkopf]], [[Renata Tebaldi]], [[Mario Lanza]], [[Jussi Björling]], [[John McCormack (tenor)|John McCormack]], [[Richard Tucker]], [[Paul Robeson]], and [[George London (bass-baritone)|George London]]; pianists [[Vladimir Horowitz]], [[Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli]], and [[Van Cliburn]]; violinists [[Jascha Heifetz]], [[Yehudi Menuhin]], and [[Tossy Spivakovsky]]; and conductors [[Leonard Bernstein]], [[Herbert von Karajan]], and [[Otto Klemperer]].
Composers [[Sergei Prokofiev]], [[Igor Stravinsky]], and [[Aaron Copland]] were managed by CAMI when they appeared as performers.
British music commentator [[Norman Lebrecht]] has criticized CAMI and Wilford for what Lebrecht deems to be overly pervasive influence of them on conductor salaries and limited time spent by music directors with orchestras.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2001/01/24/banorm24.xml Norman Lebrecht, "Could Silver Fox, the manager of maestros, be losing his grip?". ''Telegraph'', January 2001.]</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2001/01/17/banorm17.xml Norman Lebrecht, "Baton handover". ''Telegraph'', January 2001.]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Columbia Artists Management, Inc. [http://www.cami.com official website]
[[Category:1930 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]] [[Category:American companies established in 1930]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1930]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]]

{{Other uses|Criss Cross (disambiguation){{!}}Criss Cross}} {{inline|date=February 2014}} {{refimprove|date=February 2014}} '''Criss-Cross''' was an artists' co-operative that was formed in Colorado, USA, in the early 1970s. Having evolved from the 1960s artists' community, [[Drop City]], Criss-Cross focused on issues surrounding "pattern and structure" and became associated with the 1970s art movement [[Pattern and Decoration]] (P&D). In 1974, the five founders, [[Gene Bernofsky]], JoAnn Bernofsky, Richard Kallweit, Charles DiJulio and Clark Richert, artists and filmmakers from Drop City, regrouped in [[Boulder, Colorado]], to start the new artists' co-operative, Criss-Cross. Its purpose, like Drop City's, was to function in a "synergetic" interaction between peers to create experimental artistic innovation. Between 1974 and 1980, the number of participants grew to include the filmmaker [[Fred Worden]] (included in the [[2002 Whitney Biennial]]), the University of Arkansas painter/printmaker Marilyn Nelson, and the New York artists [[Gloria Klein]], [[George Woodman]] and others. Between 1974 and 1980, Criss-Cross published the nationally distributed [[Avant-garde|avant garde]] art periodical ''Criss-Cross Art Communications'' and curated national and international [[art exhibition]]s focused on "pattern and structure". Criss-Cross constructed the first "61-Zone System" (in collaboration with [[Steve Baer]] of ZomeWorks of Albuquerque, [[New Mexico]]) at the [[Art Research Center]] in Kansas City. Members of Criss-Cross included: {| |----- valign="top" | width="150pt" | '''Artists:'''

Henery Korn |} == References == * Michael Paglia, [https://den.secure.newtimes.com/issues/1997-10-09/art.html "Paint by Numbers"] {{dead link|date=February 2014}} * Michael Paglia, (July 29, 1999), [http://www.westword.com/issues/1999-07-29/art_2. "Flash Point"] {{dead link|date=February 2014}} * Michael Paglia, [http://music.westword.com/Issues/2005-03-17/culture/art.html "Cut-Ups"]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Denver Westword'', March 17, 2005 [[Category:Artist cooperatives in the United States]] [[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:Colorado culture]]
