revision.text:
'''Pierrot Barra''' (1942–1999) was a [[Haitian Vodou]] artist and priest, who was president of a [[Bizango]] society.{{cite book|last1=Cosentino|first1=Donald|last2=History|first2=University of California, Los Angeles. Fowler Museum of Cultural|title=Sacred Arts of Haitian Vodou|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YePpAAAAMAAJ|year=1995|publisher=UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural History|isbn=978-0-930741-46-4|page=25}} He was well-known for his use of diverse materials to create “Vodou Things,” which functioned as charms or altars for the Vodou religion. With his wife Marie Cassaise, he worked from the Iron Market of [[Port-au-Prince]], where he made "Vodou repositories from toys, fabric, glass, sequins, goats' horns, rosaries, costume jewelry, compact mirrors, Christmas ornaments, crucifixes, and other discarded materials."{{cite web|url=http://www.indigoarts.com/gallery_haiti_barra.html|title=The Haitian Vodou Bottles and Sculptures by Pierrot Barra|publisher=Indigoarts.com|accessdate=24 June 2015}} His Afro-Cuban dolls sold well, bought by locals to protect themselves.{{cite book|last1=Apter|first1=Andrew|last2=Derby|first2=Lauren|title=Activating the Past: History and Memory in the Black Atlantic World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LxIaBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA357|date=14 December 2009|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=978-1-4438-1790-5|page=357}} He often used discarded American toys and dolls as the basis of his works, embellishing them with "charms, glitter, sequins, beads, and crosses that were originally intended for altars."{{cite book|last=Cowen|first=Tyler|title=Creative Destruction: How Globalization Is Changing the World's Cultures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MpMSGL-rwa4C&pg=PA30|date=10 January 2009|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=1-4008-2518-0|page=30}} The most notable aspect of his works is rubber baby dolls. His works have been featured in shows in Port-au-Prince, New York, Baltimore, New Orleans, Chicago, San Francisco, and Madrid, and he is the only Haitian artist to which an entire book is dedicated (''Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise'' by Donald J. Cosentino).{{Cite journal|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|date=Winter 1999|title=Pierrot Barra|url=|journal=African Arts|volume=32|pages=16|via=}} == Biography == Some biographers believe Pierrot Barra was born in 1937, while others contend it was 1942; despite the disagreement around the specific date of his birth, it is known for certain that he was born in a district of Port-au-Prince called Bel Air. His mother, a ''mambo'' or Vodou priestess, made and sold Vodou flags at the Iron Market in Port-au-Prince.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=12}} Barra assisted his mother in her work and business for thirty years, and it was from her that he gained the necessary skills to begin making his own art. At the age of thirteen, he became an ''oungan'', or Vodou priest. He was also a part of the Bizango secret society, reaching one of its highest ranks of president.{{Cite book|title=Hidden Religion: The Greatest Mysteries and Symbols of the world's Religious Beliefs|last=Issitt|first=Micah Lee|last2=Main|first2=Carlyn|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2014|isbn=|location=Santa Barbara, California|pages=344}} While the Bizango society is feared and controversial force among the Haitian people, Barra claimed he was a member for protection. Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise, also a Vodou priestess, were married in 1971 and have been creating art together since then. Together, the two had several children, most notably Roland and Franz, who helped create pieces when Barra’s popularity grew in the late 1990’s.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=36}} Barra also had between eight and ten other wives as well, with whom he had between twenty and thirty children.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=34}} Barra died on July 31, 1999 due to heart failure. His funeral was attended by many, including art historians, customers, and foreigners who admired his work. In his stead, Marie Cassaise and his sons Roland and Franz continue to work in his style. == Works == [[File:Collectie Nationaal Museum van Wereldculturen AM-670-7 Paquet Kongo Haiti Pierot Barra (Vervaardiging).jpg|thumb|A [[paquet congo]] created by Pierrot Barra
({{ill|National Museum of World Cultures|nl|Nationaal Museum van Wereldculturen}})]] Pierrot Barra sold his work, what he calls “Vodou Things,” from a stall in the Iron Market in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. It is unknown whether Barra ever considered his pieces fine art. While Marie Cassaise is frequently credited with helping him create his work, there is very little written about her or how little or how much she contributed to the process. Many of Barra’s pieces can be considered ''gads'', very personal items imbued with spiritual power to benefit its owner, or ''reposwa'', items that contains a Haitian Vodou spirit, known as a ''lwa'' or a ''djab'' (devil), instead of altars or altar pieces.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=23–26}} Like other Haitian Vodou art, Barra’s work is filled with shiny cloth, sequins, symbols associated with the different Haitian spirits or ''lwa'', and imagery from Catholicism. This is because West African slaves brought to Haiti incorporated Catholicism into their belief system in order to gain understanding and power over their French white masters, creating what is now known as Haitian Vodou. Sequins and shimmery elements are used because they attract the Vodou lwa, in some cases for preparation for a Vodou ritual or possession (known as “riding”). The main guiding ''lwa'' of Barra’s life and art, his ''met tet'', are St. Jacques Majeur, Ezili Danto, Ogou Badagri, and Agwe.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=14}} In his dreams, sometimes these ''lwa'' commanded him to make work and other times he used the dreams for inspiration for pieces. Sometimes, the ''lwa'' would first appear to him as creatures with a hundred heads, but as he communicated more with them, he claimed they began to look like average people.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=20}} In these dreams, Barra would also see the customer who would buy the piece; he claimed each piece was for a specific person.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=15}} Barra’s works rely heavily on accumulation, a technique heavily used in Haitian and Vodou art and brought over from Africa. The changing nature of the ''lwa'' are why they love so many different kinds of materials and why so many different materials are used for sculptures, altars, and other reverent pieces. Some of his works contain ''pwen'', or points of spiritual power allowing the spirit world to seep into the world of flesh. The most iconic part of Barra’s works are the plastic dolls, which some scholars believe is his greatest contribution to Haitian art and sculpture.{{Cite journal|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|date=November 2011|title=Baby on the Blender: A Visual History of Catastrophe in Haiti|url=|journal=Small Axe|volume=15|pages=141|via=}} These dolls are not like the “voodoo” dolls of New Orleans, nor are they stuck with pins; rather they function as messengers to the spirits, represent humans or ''lwa'', or serve in place of humans for punishment or channeling magic. He claimed the materials for his pieces were always brought to him by people through the lwa as described to him in a dream, although some believe he had runners that got the materials for him. Donald Cosentino coined the term “mojo board” to describe Barra’s work that developed in the middle of his artistic career, which is a sculpture with the pieces affixed to a cloth-covered board.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=27}} This is the genre of sculpture for which Barra is most well-known. Barra’s work has been described as having an Antillean Aesthetic, but also being postmodern.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=22}}{{Cite journal|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|date=Spring 1996|title=Lavilokan|url=|journal=African Arts|volume=29|pages=28|via=}} His art is not considered traditional (although it contains traditional Vodou elements, such as sequins), but it is easily recognizable by Vodou practitioners.{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=10–11}} Even within the ever-changing culture of Vodou and Vodou art, Barra’s work has been called “revolutionary.”{{Cite book|title=Vodou Things: The Art of Pierrot Barra and Marie Cassaise|last=Cosentino|first=Donald|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1998|isbn=|location=Jackson|pages=24}} Present in Barra’s work are symbols of the Bizango spirits, a sect of the Vodou ''lwa'' pantheon. == Public collections == *[[Fowler Museum at UCLA|Fowler Museum]], Los Angeles, California *[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]], Waterloo, Iowa *[[Nottingham Contemporary|Nottingham Contemporary Art Centre]], Nottingham, England == Principle exhibitions == *1996 - ''Sacred Arts of Haitian Vodou,'' Center for the Fine Arts, Miami, Florida *2012 - ''In Extremis: Death and Life in 21st-Century Haitian Art,'' [[Fowler Museum at UCLA|Fowler Museum]], Los Angeles, California *2012 - ''Kafou: Haiti, Art & Vodou'', [[Nottingham Contemporary]], Nottingham, England *2014 - ''Haiti: Two Centuries of Art and Creativity'', [[Grand Palais]], Paris, France ==References== {{reflist}} == Additional Sources == * Brown, Karen McCarthy. “Mama Lola and the Ezilis: Themes of Mothering and Loving in Haitian Vodou.” In ''Unspoken Worlds: Women’s Religious Lives'', edited by Nancy Auer Falk and Rita M. Gross, 235-45. Cengage Learning: 2000. == External links == * [http://x-traonline.org/article/junk-yard-angel X-tra Online: Junk Yard Angel] * [https://muse.jhu.edu/article/461817 Project Muse: Baby on the Blender] * [http://indigoarts.com/artists/pierrot-barra Indigo Arts Gallery] * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/i275643 JStor: African Arts] * [http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=fc428fcd-1445-4d20-8c90-d5bf086437a1%40sessionmgr102&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#AN=2771726&db=f5h Perrot Barra Tribute] * [https://escholarship.org/uc/item/5mc5w4g2 UC Santa Barbara: Drapo Vodou] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barra, Pierrot}} [[Category:Voodoo artists]] [[Category:Haitian artists]] [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:People from Port-au-Prince]] [[Category:Haitian sculptors]]

page.title: Reel Power: Hollywood Cinema and American Supremacy

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Reel Power | image = Reelpowerdustjacket.jpg | caption = First edition, worldwide | author = [[Matthew Alford]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = [[English language|English]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]] | published = September 2010 [[Pluto Press]] (English)
March 2013 (Chinese)
September 2018 (French)
| pages = 218 (paperback) | isbn = 978-0-7453-2982-6 | isbn_note = (UK) }} '''''Reel Power: Hollywood Cinema and American Supremacy''''' is a 2010 [[Pluto Press]] book by Matthew Alford, which argues that even many of the most politically critical films, such as ''[[Hotel Rwanda]]'', ''[[Thirteen Days (film)|Thirteen Days]]'' and ''[[Three Kings (1999 film)|Three Kings]]'', provide favourable mythology for the United States' government. Alford draws attention to the power of corporate moguls and the role of the government in the production of various films, such as ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]'', ''[[Terminator Salvation]]'', and ''[[Transformers]]''. The foreword is written by [[Michael Parenti]]. A French translation emerged in August 2018, with a new preface. == Reception == In the British ''[[Morning Star (UK newspaper)|Morning Star]]'', James Walsh commented that the book "is an engaging look at the innards of the dream factory process" and that although the revelations of film-maker collusion with the Pentagon are not surprising "the details are fascinating" especially in relation to "films traditionally considered nuanced or critical of US foreign policy".James Walsh [http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/index.php/news/content/view/full/97424 Review: ''Reel Power'',] ''Morning Star'', 9 November 2010 ''[[The Journal of Popular Culture]]'' called it "One part cultural studies analysis, and another part expose", adding that it "offers a salient critique for those who are concerned about the long term implications of the power of film to act as site of ideological instruction".Journal of Popular Culture Volume 45, Number 4 (August 2012), p. 908-10 Contemporary Sociology called it "an attractive and up-to-date set of tools for the critical literacy that should be mandatory in today’s media-saturated environments".Contemporary Sociology: A Journal of Reviews July 2011 vol. 40 no. 4 501 Simon Kinnear from ''[[Total Film]]'' gave ''Reel Power'' four stars out of five and called it a "laudable study" and "an eye opening expose". "Alford's occasionally guilty of straw-clutching", he said, "but you'll watch the next gung-ho blockbuster a little closer".Simon Kinnear "Reel Power: Book Review", ''Total Film'', December 2010, p.160 In ''[[Lobster Magazine]]'', [[Robin Ramsay (editor)|Robin Ramsay]] observes that "If Alford isn’t quite describing the corporations and the state running joint psy-ops, it will do until joint psy-ops come along". Ramsay reviews the book as "competently done, decently written and, if you’ve seen a lot of American movies – and I have – it is interesting to have the ideological content articulated. I could do it myself, and I’m sort of subliminally aware of it; but most of the time I’m just watching the movie. So the author’s considerable efforts are both useful and entertaining"Robin Ramsay [http://www.lobster-magazine.co.uk/free/lobster60/lobster60.pdf Book Review: Reel Power,] ''Lobster'', Winter 2010, pp. 148-150 == Criticisms == Roy Stafford, former editor of ''In the Picture'' magazine, says that ''Reel Power'' is a "solid introduction" to Hollywood and American politics but one which is a journalistic popularisation of Alford's more overtly academic work and as such, he implies unfortunately, "renders much that Film Studies has tried to do over the last fifty years... as effectively wasted effort."Roy Stafford [http://itpworld.wordpress.com/2010/10/15/reel-power-hollywood-cinema-and-american-supremacy/ Book Review: ''The Case for Global Film''], 15 October 2010 In ''[[The Scotsman]]'', Hannah McGill, artistic director of the [[Edinburgh International Film Festival]] opined that ''Reel Power'' "has its valid points to make [and] is at its best when it identifies and analyses cases of direct influence being brought to bear on film production by the US political establishment [...] its stonewalling of more contentious projects [...] or individuals in positions of constant influence" but that "I felt, on frequent occasion, as if I was in the company of the character Jane Horrocks played in Mike Leigh's [[Life Is Sweet (film)|Life is Sweet]]: the moodily self-righteous teen who hurled the word "FASCIST!" at anyone who failed to mirror her every conviction and desire" [http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/books/Book-review-Reel-Power.6572532.jp?articlepage=1 Book Review: Reel Power,] ''The Scotsman'', 9 October 2010 ==Further Work== A 2017 book, ''[[National Security Cinema]]: The Shocking New Evidence of Government Control in Hollywood'', by Matthew Alford and archivist Tom Secker, updates some of the case studies and uses the Freedom of Information Act to establish more specifically how certain films and TV shows have been affected by [[The Pentagon]] and [[CIA]]. ==See also== *[[Investigative journalism]] *[[Military-industrial complex]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php?title=Matthew_Alford Matthew Arnold] at [[SourceWatch]] [[Category:Debut books]]

revision.comment: fixed [[MOS:DASH|dashes]] using a [[User:GregU/dashes.js|script]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Batik Indonesia.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Indonesian batik fabric]]
'''Resist dyeing''' ('''resist-dyeing''') is a traditional method of [[dyeing]] [[textile]]s with patterns. Methods are used to "[[resist]]" or prevent the dye from reaching all the cloth, thereby creating a pattern and ground. The most common forms use [[wax]], some type of paste made from starch or mud,<ref name="BGAfrica">{{cite web|title=Batik in Africa |url=http://www.batikguild.org.uk/historyAfrica.asp | publisher=The Batik Guild| accessdate=April 29, 2014 }}</ref> or a mechanical resist that manipulates the cloth such as tying or stitching. Another form of resist involves using a chemical agent in a specific type of dye that will repel another type of dye [[textile printing|printed]] over the top. The best-known varieties today include [[tie-dye]] and [[batik]].
==Basic methods== '''Wax or paste''': melted [[wax]] or some form of paste is applied to cloth before being dipped in dye. Wherever the wax has seeped through the fabric, the dye will not penetrate. Sometimes several colors are used, with a series of dyeing, drying and waxing steps. The wax may also be applied to another piece of cloth to make a [[stencil]], which is then placed over the cloth, and dye applied to the assembly; this is known as '''resist printing'''.
'''Stencils''': a [[stencil]] is placed over the fabric where it is to be shielded from ink, similar to how [[screenprinting|screen prints]] are made.
'''Mechanical''': the cloth is tied, stitched, or clamped using clothespegs or wooden blocks to shield areas of the fabric.
'''Chemical''': a modern textile printing method, commonly achieved using two different classes of fiber [[reactive dyes]], one of which must be of the vinyl sulfone type. A chemical-resisting agent is combined with dye Type A, and printed using the [[screenprint]] method and allowed to dry. A second dye, Type B, is then printed overtop. The resist agent in Type A chemically prevents Type B from reacting with the fabric, resulting in a crisp pattern/ground relationship.<ref name="chemicalresist">{{cite web |title = Vinyl Sulfone Fiber Reactive Dyes: Using Remazol Dyes for Chemical Resist Dyeing |url=http://www.pburch.net/dyeing/remazol.shtml#chemicalresist |publisher=All About Hand Dyeing |date=September 30, 2011 |accessdate = April 13, 2016}} </ref>
==History== Resist dyeing has been very widely used in Eurasia and Africa since ancient times. The first discoveries of pieces of linen was from Egypt and date from the fourth century. Cloth, used for mummy wrappings, was coated with wax, scratched with a sharp stylus, and dyed with a mixture of blood and ashes. After dyeing the cloth was washed in hot water to remove the wax. In Asia, this technique was practiced in China during the T'ang dynasty (618–907), in India and Japan in the Nara period (645–794). In Africa it was originally practiced by the Yoruba tribe in Nigeria, Soninke and Wolof in Senegal.<ref name="BGAfrica"/>
==Traditions using wax or paste== * [[Guizhou|Guizhou Province]] of China had a strong tradition of wax dyeing
[[Image:Roketsuzome printing wheels.jpg|thumb|200px|Rōketsuzome printing wheels at Roketsuzome Yamamoto, [[Kyoto]].]] * [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]] and [[India]] – [[Batik]] with wax * [[Japan]] – [[Rōketsuzome]] with wax, [[Katazome]], Yūzen and [[Tsutsugaki]] with rice-paste * [[Africa]] – Yoruba people of [[Nigeria]] uses cassava paste as a resist while the people of [[Senegal]] use rice paste. Among other terms, [[Madiba shirt|Madiba]].<ref name="BGAfrica"/>
==Traditions using tying or stitching== * [[Indonesia]] and [[Malaysia]] – [[Ikat]], where only the [[warp (weaving)|warp]] or [[weft]] is dyed (article covers similar techniques elsewhere). * [[India]] * Africa – [[Adire (textile art)|Adire]] * Modern West – [[Tie-dye]] * Japan – [[Shibori]]
==Traditions using printing== * [[Japan]]- [[Katazome|Katagami]] and [[Bingata]] with stencils * [[China]] – about 500 AD the ''jia xie'' method for dyeing (usually silk) using wood blocks was invented. An upper and a lower block is made, with carved out compartments opening to the back, fitted with plugs. The cloth, usually folded a number of times, is inserted and clamped between the two blocks. By unplugging the different compartments and filling them with dyes of different colours, a multi-coloured pattern can be printed over quite a large area of folded cloth.<ref name="cave">Shelagh Vainker in Anne Farrer (ed), "Caves of the Thousand Buddhas" , 1990, British Museum publications, {{ISBN|0-7141-1447-2}}</ref>
==Other traditions== [[Image:UkiePysanky2006.jpg|thumb|A mix of modern and traditional Ukrainian [[pysanky]]]] * [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]] and [[Poland]] – [[Pysanka]], with wax for eggs at [[Easter]]
==See also== *[[Woodblock printing]] *[[Byzantine dress]]
==References== <references/>
{{Dyeing}}
[[Category:Textile arts]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical composition | name = Symphony No. 1 | composer = [[Peter Maxwell Davies]] | image = Peter Maxwell Davies.jpg | caption = The composer in 2012 | key = | catalogue = | composed = {{start date|1973}}–1976 | dedication = [[William Glock]] | published = | movements = 4 | premiere_date = {{start date|1978|02|02|df=y}} | premiere_location = [[Royal Festival Hall]], London | premiere_conductor = [[Simon Rattle]] | premiere_performers = [[Philharmonia Orchestra]] | first_recording = {{start date|1978|08|df=y}} }} The '''Symphony No. 1''' by [[Peter Maxwell Davies]] was composed between 1973 and 1976, and is dedicated to Sir [[William Glock]], "as a mark of friendship and of appreciation of his work for contemporary music in his years as music controller at the B.B.C." {{harv|Davies|1978|loc=5}}. It was commissioned by the [[Philharmonia Orchestra]], which gave the premiere of the symphony at the [[Royal Festival Hall]], London, on 2 February 1978, with [[Simon Rattle]] conducting.
==Character and materials== In his First Symphony, Davies addresses both the [[Beethoven]] model of the symphony and [[Sibelius]]'s reinterpretation of it {{harv|Pruslin|1978|loc=7}}. Davies began work on what would become his First Symphony in 1973: a commission by the Philharmonia Orchestra intended to be performed the next year, resulting in a single-movement work of moderate length, provisionally titled ''Black Pentecost''. However, the composer withdrew this score before it could be performed, feeling that it was not complete and needed to extend beyond the already-finished movement. In order to increase his understanding of large-scale orchestral composition, Davies analysed a number of other composers' works, and cites Sibelius's [[Symphony No. 5 (Sibelius)|Fifth Symphony]], the opening of Schumann's [[Symphony No. 2 (Schumann)|Second Symphony]], and the first movement, "Don", from Pierre Boulez's ''[[Pli selon pli]]'' as precedents for specific moments of the composition. As the work evolved, Davies came to the conviction that it "could mark the possibility of a beginning of an orchestral competence", and so decided to designate it a Symphony. The pitches, note values, and longer time-spans are shaped and transformed by [[magic squares]]. Several [[plainsongs]] occur, and are transformed from one into another. The overall tonal centre is F, with a "modal dominant" of D{{Music|flat}} {{harv|Davies|1978|loc=2–3}}.
==Instrumentation== The symphony is scored for piccolo (doubling alto flute), two flutes (second doubling second piccolo), two oboes, cor anglais, two clarinets, bass clarinet, two bassoons, double bassoon, four horns, three trumpets, three trombones, timpani, four percussionists (playing marimba, tubular bells, [[flexatone]], glockenspiel, and crotales), harp, celesta, and strings.
==Analysis== The symphony is in four movements: # Presto – Allegro molto – Allegro sempre # Lento – Andante con moto – Allegro moderato – Allegro – Allegro vivo – Presto – Poco meno presto # Adagio – Più lento # Presto
After brass and pizzicato strings introduce the basic harmonies of the movement, the symphony proceeds as an allegro movement with "a ghost of a sonata form somewhere behind it", though there are no distinct first and second themes, and development is replaced by processes of transformation {{harv|Davies|1978|loc=3}}.
The second movement is a lento that turns into a scherzo, beginning with a statement of the plainsong [[Ave maris stella]] in the alto flute. It has D as its tonic, and a modal dominant of F{{Music|sharp}} {{harv|Davies|1978|loc=2, 4}}.
The third movement is the slow movement proper, and has as its tonic the previous movement’s modal dominant, F{{Music|sharp}}, and the corresponding modal dominant A{{Music|sharp}}/B{{Music|flat}} and becomes an invocation of the "extraordinary, almost unearthly, treeless winter land and seascape of the Orkney island" where the composer lives {{harv|Davies|1978|loc=2, 4}}.
The finale parallels the tonal shape of the first. It reaches a climax with an emergence of the "Ave maris stella" material in the form found in Davies's composition of the same title {{harv|Davies|1978|loc=4}}. The silences broken by jabbed chords at the end of the movement refers to the endings of the Fifth Symphonies of both Beethoven and Sibelius. The relationship to Beethoven is expressed exclusively in terms of rhythm {{harv|Pruslin|1978|loc=8}}.
==Discography== * ''Peter Maxwell Davies: Symphony''. Philharmonia Orchestra, Simon Rattle (cond.). Recorded August 1978 in the Kingsway Hall, London. 12-inch LP recording. Headline. Decca HEAD 21. (TT: 54 min.) London: Decca, 1978. Reissued as part of ''Simon Rattle & Peter Maxwell Davies: Symphony No. 1; Points and Dances from Taverner''. ''Points and Dances'' performed by The Fires of London, Peter Maxwell Davies (cond.). Twenty-fifth anniversary edition. CD recording. UCJ 473-721-2. (TT: 71:31). [England]: UCJ, 2003. * ''Maxwell Davies: Symphony no. 1''. BBC Philharmonic Orchestra, Sir Peter Maxwell Davies (cond.). Recorded by arrangement with BBC North at Studio 7, New Broadcasting House, Manchester, 8–9 December 1994. CD recording. Collins Classics 14352. (TT: 54:53). [England]: Lambourne Productions Limited, 1995. Reissued as part of ''Peter Maxwell Davies: Symphony No. 1 / Mavis in Las Vegas''. CD recording. 8.572348. (TT: 68:03). [[Naxos Records]], 2012.
==References== *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Adlington|1996}}|reference=Adlington, Robert. 1996. "Grammar-School Boys". ''The Musical Times'' 137, no. 1835 (January): 35–37.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Davies|1978}}|reference=Davies, Peter Maxwell. 1978. "Symphony". ''Tempo'', new series, no. 124 (March): 2–5.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Gloag|2009}}|reference=Gloag, Kenneth. 2009. "Questions of Form and Genre in Peter Maxwell Davies's First Symphony". In ''Peter Maxwell Davies Studies'', edited by Kenneth Gloag and Nicholas Jones, 129–49. Cambridge Composer Studies. Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|9780521886581}} (cloth); {{ISBN|978-0521182720}} (pbk).}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Jones|2002}}|reference=Jones, Nicholas. 2002. "Peter Maxwell Davies's Basic Unifying Hypothesis: Dominant Logic". ''The Musical Times'' 143, no. 1878 (Spring): 37–45.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Keller|1978}}|reference=Keller, Hans. 1978. "The State of the Symphony: Not Only Maxwell Davies's". ''Tempo'', new series, no. 125 (June): 6–11.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Lister|2009}}|reference=Lister, Rodney. 2009. "The Ghost in the Machine: Sonata Form in the Music of Peter Maxwell Davies". In ''Peter Maxwell Davies Studies'', edited by Kenneth Gloag and Nicholas Jones, 106–28. Cambridge Composer Studies. Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-521-18272-0}}.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|McGregor|2000}}|reference=McGregor, Richard. 2000. "Reading the Runes". ''Perspectives of New Music'' 38, No. 2 (Summer): 5–29.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Owens|1994}}|reference=Owens, Peter. 1994. "Revelation and Fallacy: Observations on Compositional Technique in the Music of Peter Maxwell Davies". ''Music Analysis'' 13, nos. 2–3 (October): 161–202.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Pruslin|1978}}|reference=Pruslin, Stephen. 1978. "Maxwell Davies's Symphony: An Introduction". ''Tempo'', new series, no. 124 (March): 6–9.}} *{{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Warnaby|2001}}|reference=Warnaby, John. 2001. "Davies, Peter Maxwell". ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (professor of music)|John Tyrrell]]. London: Macmillan Publishers.}}
{{Davies symphonies}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith | image = The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith.jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Fred Schepisi]] | producer = [[Fred Schepisi]] | writer = [[Fred Schepisi]] | based on = novel by [[Thomas Keneally]] | starring =[[Tom E. Lewis]]
[[Angela Punch McGregor]] | music = [[Bruce Smeaton]] | cinematography = [[Ian Baker (cinematographer)|Ian Baker]] | editing = [[Brian Kavanagh (filmmaker)|Brian Kavanagh]] | studio = | distributor = [[Hoyts]]
[[Umbrella Entertainment]]
Industrial Entertainment (U.S. DVD release) | released = {{film date|1978|6|21|df=yes}} | runtime = 120 minutes | country = Australia | language = English | budget = A$1,200,000David Stratton, ''The Last New Wave: The Australian Film Revival'', Angus & Robertson, 1980 p134-137 | gross = A$1,021,000 (Australia) }} '''''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith''''' is a 1978 Australian [[drama film]] directed, written and produced by [[Fred Schepisi]], and starring [[Tom E. Lewis]] (billed at the time as Tommy Lewis), Freddy Reynolds and [[Ray Barrett]].[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/60699 The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978)] at [[British Film Institute]] website The film also featured early appearances by [[Bryan Brown]], [[Arthur Dignam]], and [[John Jarratt]]. It is an adaptation of the novel ''[[The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith]]'' by [[Thomas Keneally]]. The story is about an exploited [[Indigenous Australian|Aboriginal Australian]] who commits murder and goes into hiding. It is based on actual events surrounding [[Jimmy Governor]]. For Schepisi the film's reception was a disillusioning experience and he left Australia soon after to work in Hollywood, returning to Australia ten years later to make ''[[Evil Angels (film)|Evil Angels]]''.''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith'' at the [http://australianscreen.com.au/titles/chant-jimmie-blacksmith/ Australian screen]{{cite book|editor-last=Murray |editor-first=Scott |title=Australian Cinema|publisher=Allen & Unwin/AFC|location= St.Leonards, NSW.|year=1994|page=85|isbn=1863733116}} While not prosecuted for obscenity, the film was seized and confiscated in the UK under Section 3 of the [[Obscene Publications Act 1959]] during the [[video nasty]] panic. == Plot == Jimmie Blacksmith, a half-caste child of an Aboriginal mother and a white father, is raised to adulthood by the Reverend Neville and his wife Martha, hoping their influence will civilize him and provide him greater opportunities in early twentieth century Australia. With a letter of recommendation from his foster family, he goes out in search of work to establish himself, but is taken advantage of by multiple parties. His first employer, Healey, repeatedly shortchanges his pay by nitpicking his fencebuilding work, and refuses to write a job recommendation to avoid admitting he himself is illiterate. Jimmie then works for a local constable, Farrell, who uses him as muscle against other local Aboriginals, including capturing a former friend who is later molested and murdered while in custody, and forced to cover up the death. Jimmie finds some stability working on the farm of the Newby family, who still treat him little better than other employers, and decides to summon and marry a white girlfriend, Gilda Marshall, who is already very pregnant when she arrives to move in with him. Gilda later gives birth to a white child, obviously not fathered by Jimmie; while upset at the public embarrassment, he eagerly embraces being a parent. Shortly after the birth, Jimmie's full-caste brother Mort and uncle Tabidgi come to the Newby property, and Jimmie enlists their help in his fence-building work. However, Mr. Newby uses their presence as an excuse to deny Jimmie his pay and needed provisions, claiming the extra men were not part of their arrangement. Meanwhile, Mrs. Newby and a schoolteacher friend Miss Graf try to convince Gilda to take her baby and leave Jimmie for a teaching opportunity in another part of the country, which Gilda refuses. Furious at the mistreatment his family is facing, Jimmie enlists Tabidgi to help put a "scare" into the Newby women while the men are away, planning to threaten them with hatchets. This suddenly and brutally turns into a rampage that leaves Mrs. Newby, Miss Graf, and all the Newby daughters but one infant dead. Jimmie's family flee the compound, and shortly after Tabidgi, Gilda, and the child are left behind as Jimmie and Mort continue on the run. They soon murder Jimmie's previous employer Healey as well, with Jimmie announcing that he has declared war, in the manner he once heard the fighting against the Boers described. As press coverage about Jimmie's killings become nationwide news, a reporter makes regular probing inquiries to his butcher, whom he is aware doubles as the city's hangman for the police, about what may take place when Jimmie is captured. Tabidgi, since captured and sentenced to death for accessory to murder, tells the convicting court that the decision to kill was not part of the plan and came to them on impulse. Still uncaptured, Jimmie and Mort come upon a schoolteacher, McCready, who they initially wound by gunfire; he convinces them not to kill him by showing them a newspaper article about their national notoriety. They decide to take him as a hostage instead and take him from his home. As the brothers argue about the morality of their crimes of killing women and children, McCready makes bitterly humorous observations about the influence of white people on the native Aboriginies. He convinces Jimmie to go on alone and abandon Mort by indicating that Mort's soul has had none of Jimmie's detrimental white influences. Mort in turn takes McCready to a farm to recover, but is killed by a hunting party led by the Newby males and Miss Graf's fiancee Dowie Steed. Jimmie himself is shot at in a lake, but manages to crudely tend to his wounds and hide out in a convent for a night. He is found the next morning and taken by police, who vainly try to prevent townspeople from beating him as they take him to jail. In the final scene, Jimmie is read the last rites by Rev. Neville in his cell, as the butcher/hangman from earlier observes them, and declares that despite the (perceived) unique physical characteristics of Jimmie, his hanging will likely go as normal as any other. == Cast == * [[Tom E. Lewis]] as Jimmie Blacksmith (credited as "Tommy Lewis") * Freddy Reynolds as Mort Blacksmith * [[Ray Barrett]] as Farrell * [[Jack Thompson (actor)|Jack Thompson]] as Rev. Neville * [[Angela Punch McGregor]] as Gilda Marshall (credited as "Angela Punch") * [[Steve Dodd]] as Tabidgi * [[Peter Carroll (actor)|Peter Carroll]] as McCready * [[Ruth Cracknell]] as Mrs. Heather Newby * [[Don Crosby]] as Newby * [[Elizabeth Alexander (actress)|Elizabeth Alexander]] as Petra Graf * [[Peter Sumner]] as Dowie Steed * [[Tim Robertson]] as Healey * [[Ray Meagher]] as Dud Edmonds * Brian Anderson as Hyberry * Jane Harders as Mrs. Healey == Production == The film's budget was raised from a variety of sources; $350,000 plus a loan of $50,000 from the [[Australian Film Commission]], $350,000 from the [[Victorian Film Corporation]], $200,000 from [[Hoyts]], $250,000 from Schepisi. [[Tom E. Lewis|Tommy Lewis]] was spotted by Fred Schepisi's wife at Melbourne airport just walking past. He was approached and was eventually cast.David Roe & [[Scott Murray (filmmaker)|Scott Murray]], "Fred Schepisi", ''[[Cinema Papers]]'', January 1978 p244-246, 269 Filming began on 8 August 1977 and went for fourteen weeks. == Awards == The film won the Best Original Music Score (Bruce Smeaton), Best Actress in a Lead Role (Angela Punch McGregor) and Best Actor in a Supporting Role (Ray Barrett) and was nominated for 9 more awards at the [[Australian Film Institute]] (AFI) for 1978. It was also nominated for the [[Palme d'Or]] (Golden Palm) at the [[1978 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1958/year/1978.html |title=Festival de Cannes: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith |accessdate=21 May 2009|work=festival-cannes.com}} The novel was nominated for the [[Man Booker Prize|Booker Prize]] in 1972, losing to [[John Berger]]'s [[G. (novel)|G.]] == Box office == ''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith'' grossed $1,021,000 at the box office in Australia.[http://film.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/AA4_Aust_Box_office_report.pdf ''Film Victoria – Australian Films at the Australian Box Office''] Because of the promotional costs involved, only $50,000 was returned to the producers. Schepisi lost his entire investment. == Home media == ''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith'' was released on DVD with a new print by [[Umbrella Entertainment]] in November 2008. The DVD is compatible with all region codes and includes special features such as the theatrical trailer and audio commentary with Fred Schepisi. The 30th Anniversary Edition also includes interviews with key cast and crew including Fred Schepisi and Tommy Lewis, a Q&A session with Fred Schepisi and Geoffrey Rush filmed at the Melbourne International Film Festival in 2008, a stills gallery and ''Making Us Blacksmiths'', a documentary on the casting of Aboriginal lead actors Tommy Lewis and Freddy Reynolds.{{cite web|title=Umbrella Entertainment – 30th Anniversary Edition|url=http://www.umbrellaent.com.au/p-2095-chant-of-jimmie-blacksmith-the-30th-anniversary-edition.aspx|accessdate=8 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=Umbrella Entertainment – Single DVD|url=http://www.umbrellaent.com.au/p-2367-chant-of-jimmie-blacksmith-the-single-dvd-edition.aspx|accessdate=8 May 2013}} Many of the features of this disc were ported over for a U.S. DVD release from studio Industrial Entertainment, but is now out-of-print. == Reception == The film holds a [[List of films with a 100% rating on Rotten Tomatoes|100% approval rating]] on [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]].{{citeweb|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1201493_chant_of_jimmie_blacksmith?|title=''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith'' (1978)|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=16 March 2018}} == Other == "The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith" by Australian roots-rock band [[The Groovesmiths]] is also based on the story. == See also == * [[Cinema of Australia]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0077318|title=The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith}} *[http://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/chant-of-jimmie-blacksmith ''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith''] at Oz Movies * [http://archive.sensesofcinema.com/contents/cteq/00/9/chant.html Analysis by Allan James Thomas who teaches Documentary Film Theory at RMIT and La Trobe Universities] *[https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1201493_chant_of_jimmie_blacksmith? ''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith''] at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] * [http://colsearch.nfsa.afc.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=44726;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith at the National Film and Sound Archive] {{AACTAAward BestMusicScore 1975-1979}} {{Fred Schepisi}} {{Films and television series about Aboriginal Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chant Of Jimmie Blacksmith, The}} [[Category:1978 films]] [[Category:1970s drama films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:Australian drama films]] [[Category:Bushranger films]] [[Category:Australian Western (genre) films]] [[Category:Films based on Australian novels]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films set in 1900]] [[Category:Films set in 1901]] [[Category:Films set in colonial Australia]] [[Category:Films directed by Fred Schepisi]] [[Category:Films about Aboriginal Australians]]

page.title: The Creation of the Sun, Moon and Vegetation

revision.comment: removed 'stupendous'
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Michelangelo, Creation of the Sun, Moon, and Plants 01.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = The Creation of the Sun, Moon and Vegetation | artist = [[Michelangelo]] | year = 1511 | type = [[Fresco]] | height_metric = 280 | width_metric = 570 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Sistine Chapel]], [[Vatican City]] | museum = }} '''''The Creation of the Sun, Moon and Vegetation''''', (sometimes '''''The Creation of the Sun, Moon, and Plants'''''<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.wga.hu/frames-e.html?/html/m/michelan/3sistina/1genesis/8plants/08_3ce8.html| title =Creation of the Sun, Moon, and Plants |publisher =Web Gallery of Art| accessdate = 13 Jan 2014}}</ref> or '''''The Creation of the Sun and the Moon''''') is one of the [[fresco]]es from [[Michelangelo]]'s nine [[Book of Genesis]] scenes on the [[Sistine Chapel ceiling]]. It is the second scene in the chronological sequence on the ceiling, depicting the third and fourth day of the [[Genesis creation narrative|Creation narrative]].
On the left side of the painting God is depicted from behind, extending his arm towards a bush, alluding to the plant world. On the right side another image of God points towards the Sun with his right hand and toward the faint Moon with his left. His face expresses the force needed for the creation of the abode of living beings. The abstract patterns of [[drapery]] emphasize the motion of both figures of God.
''The Creation of the Sun, Moon and Planets'' is featured on the postage stamps of Vatican City (issue of 1994) and India (issue of 1975).
[[File:Michelangelo Buonarroti 018.jpg|thumb|306px|The painting before the [[restoration of the Sistine Chapel frescoes]]]].
==References== {{reflist}} {{commons category|Sistine Chapel ceiling - Creation of the Sun, Moon, and Planets}}
{{Michelangelo}} {{Sistine Chapel|state=expanded}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Creation of the Sun, Moon and Planets}} [[Category:Sistine Chapel ceiling]] [[Category:1511 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Hebrew Bible themes]] [[Category:Paintings of gods]] [[Category:Moon in art]]

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Haywain (painting)|the painting by John Constable|The Hay Wain}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Bosch - Haywain Triptych.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 450px | title = The Haywain Triptych | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Hieronymus Bosch]] | year = c. 1516 | material = | height_metric = 135 | width_metric = 200 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | city = [[Madrid]] | museum = [[Museo del Prado]] }} The '''''Haywain Triptych''''' is a [[panel painting]] by [[Hieronymus Bosch]], currently housed in the [[Museo del Prado]], Madrid, Spain. A date of around 1516 has been established by means of [[dendrochronology|dendrochronological]] research. The central panel, signed "Jheronimus Bosch", measures 135 by 200 centimeters and the wings measure 147 × 66 cm. The outside shutters feature a version of Bosch's ''[[The Wayfarer]]''.
==History== The painting was part of a group of six acquired by king [[Philip II of Spain]] in 1570, and shipped to [[El Escorial]] four years later. It was later sold to the Marquis of Salamanca, and divided into three paintings. In 1848, the central panel was bought by [[Isabella II of Spain]] and brought to [[Aranjuez]], the right one was returned to Escorial and the left went to the Prado. The triptych was finally recomposed in 1914 in the latter museum.<ref name="Var160">{{cite book|first=Franca |last=Varallo|title=Bosch |publisher=Skira|location=Milan|year=2004|page=160}}</ref> A copy exists at the Escorial.
[[file:The Pedlar, closed state of The Hay Wain by Hieronymus Bosch.jpg|240px|thumb|The closed triptych]]
==Description==
===Shutters=== The exterior of the shutters, like most contemporary Netherlandish triptychs, were also painted, although in this case Bosch used full colors instead of the usual [[grisaille]]. When closed, they form a single scene depicting a wayfarer. Around him is a series of miniatures including the robbery of another wayfarer and a hanged man. The man uses a stick to repel a dog.
According to the most recent interpretations, this figure may represent the man who follows his road in spite of the temptation of sins (such as lust, perhaps symbolized by the two dancing shepherds) and the evil acts occurring around him.<ref name="Var160"/>
===Main panels=== The Haywain triptych follows a similar narrative to ''[[The Garden of Earthly Delights]]''. The left panel shows God giving form to [[Eve]]. Unlike the ''Garden'', though, a narrative sequence flows through the panel in different scenes. At the top, the rebel angels are cast out of Heaven while God sits enthroned, the angels turning into insects as they break through the clouds. Below this, God creates Eve from the rib of Adam. Next, Adam and Eve find the serpent and the tree; [[Serpent (Bible)|the serpent]] offers them an apple. Finally, at the lowest part of the panel, the angel forces the two out of the [[Garden of Eden]]. Adam speaks with the angel; Eve, in a melancholic pose, looks ahead to the right.
The central panel features a large wagon of hay surrounded by a multitude of fools engaged in a variety of sins, quite apart from the sins of lust which dominates the ''Garden of Earthly Delights''. In the center panel Bosch shows [[Christ]] in the sky, not paralleled in the ''Garden''. An angel on top of the wagon looks to the sky, praying, but none of the other figures see Christ looking down on the world. The rightward bow of the figures around the wagon provides the force for the viewer’s eye to move with them on their journey and the cart is drawn by infernal beings which drag everyone to [[Hell]], depicted on the right panel.
The forward kinetic motion of the participants moves the viewer from present-day sin into unadulterated torture in the realms of Hell. The procession on the left side of this panel bends back into the middle ground, but the right side figures continue in a straight line with the wagon, a more evident progress into damnation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Minnick|first=Nathaniel|title=Hieronymus Bosch’s Triptychs in the Netherlandish Tradition|publisher=University of Michigan|year=2005}}</ref>
==Painting materials== The triptych was thoroughly investigated by the scientists at the Bosch Research and Conservation Project<ref>[http://boschproject.org/ The Bosch Research and Conservation Project]</ref> with the results published in book form.<ref>Luuk Hoogstede, Ron Spronk, Matthijs Ilsink, Robert G. Erdmann, Jos Koldeweij, Rik Klein Gotink, Hieronymus Bosch, Painter and Draughtsman: Technical Studies, Yale University Press, 2016, pp. 296–313.</ref> Bosch's palette was rather limited with [[pigments]] including [[azurite]], [[lead-tin-yellow|lead-tin yellow]], [[vermilion]] and [[ochres]].<ref>[http://colourlex.com/project/hieronymus-bosch-haywain-triptych/ Hieronymus Bosch, ''The Haywain Triptych''], ColourLex</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|The Haywain Triptych (Prado)|''The Haywain Triptych'' (Prado)}} *[http://www.scholarsresource.com/browse/museum/6109 ''The Haywain Triptych'' at El Escorial] *[http://colourlex.com/project/hieronymus-bosch-haywain-triptych/ Hieronymus Bosch, ''The Haywain Triptych''], ColourLex
{{Hieronymus Bosch}} {{Adam and Eve}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Haywain Triptych, The}} [[Category:Paintings by Hieronymus Bosch]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Jesus]] [[Category:Triptychs]] [[Category:1516 paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the Museo del Prado]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Adam and Eve]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Farming in art]] [[Category:Horses in art]] [[Category:Insects in art]] [[Category:Snakes in art]] [[Category:Dogs in art]]

revision.text:
{{update|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox islands | name = The World Islands (Dubai) | native_name = <!-- or local name to remove the "native name:" prefix --> | sobriquet = <!-- or nickname --> | image_name = Dubaiworld.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = View of The World in early 2009 | image_alt = | map_image = Dubai new developments.png | map_size = 300 | map_caption = | location = [[United Arab Emirates]] | coordinates = {{coord|25|13|00|N|55|10|00|E|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = The World | total_islands = | major_islands = | area_km2 = <!-- or area m2 or area ha --> | area_footnotes = | rank = | length_km = 9 | width_km = 6 | width_footnotes = | coastline_km = <!-- or coastline m --> | coastline_footnotes = | elevation_m = | elevation_footnotes = | highest_mount = <!--name--> | country = [[United Arab Emirates]] | demonym = | population = | population_as_of = | density_km2 = | density_footnotes = | ethnic_groups = | website = {{URL|www.nakheel.com}} | additional_info = '''Developer:''' [[Nakheel]] }} [[File:The world Dubai.jpg|thumb|right|450px|The development's logo]] '''The World''' or '''The World Islands, located in Dubai,''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: جزر العالم; ''Juzur al-Ālam'') is an [[Artificial island|artificial]] [[archipelago]] of various small [[island]]s constructed in the rough shape of a [[world map]], located in the waters of the [[Persian Gulf]], {{Convert|4.0|km|mi}} off the coast of [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="Progress Update">{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/133896.html |publisher=''[[AMEInfo]]'' |title=Dubai's Palm and World Islands - progress update |date=2007-10-04 |accessdate=2008-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011022845/http://www.ameinfo.com/133896.html |archivedate=2007-10-11 |df= }}</ref> The World islands are composed mainly of sand [[dredging|dredged]] from Dubai's shallow coastal waters, and are one of several [[artificial island]] developments in Dubai.<ref name="Progress Update"/> The World's developer is [[Nakheel Properties]], and the project was originally conceived by [[Sheikh]] [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], the ruler of Dubai. The actual construction was done by two Dutch (joint venture) specialist companies, Van Oord and Boskalis. The same companies also created the [[Palm Jumeirah]].
Construction of the 300 islands began in 2003, only to halt due to the [[2008 financial crisis]].<ref name="Sinking">{{cite news|title='The World' is sinking|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/travel/international/4594274/The-World-is-sinking|accessdate=28 January 2011|newspaper=The Age|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> Though 60 percent of the islands had been sold off to private contractors back in 2008, development on most of these islands has failed to initiate.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schaffer|first1=Sierra|title=The "World" Is Sinking Back Into The Sea, Dubai's World Islands That Is – TechMalak|url=https://www.techmalak.com/the-world-is-sinking-back-into-the-sea-dubais-world-that-is/#.WS2awHXyukA|work=TechMalak|date=23 May 2016}}</ref> As of July 2012, the Lebanon Island was developed and was the only island that had so far been developed commercially, being used for private corporate events and public parties. As of late 2013, only two of the islands had been developed. In January 2014, Kleindienst Group announced the launch of "The Heart of Europe" project;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/january2014/ |title= KLEINDIENST GROUP LAUNCHES ICONIC THE HEART OF EUROPE PROJECT|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= January 2014 |publisher= JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> by February 2014, one of Kleindienst Group's brands - JK Properties - announced in their monthly newsletter that the project was "well underway".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/february2014/ |title= WORK CONTINUES TO PROGRESS AT A PACE ON THE HEART OF EUROPE |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= February 2014 |publisher= JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> The first of these series of islands will be Europe, Sweden and Germany with development led by Kleindienst Group.
==Project== Islands in the project range from {{convert|14000|to|42000|m2|sqft}} in area.<ref name="Progress Update"/> Distances between islands average {{convert|100|m|ft}}; they are constructed from {{convert|321,000,000|m3|abbr=out}} of sand and 386 million tons of rock.<ref name="Progress Update"/> Designed by [[Creative Kingdom Dubai]], the development is an area that covers {{convert|6|by|9|km|mi}} and is surrounded by an oval-shaped [[Breakwater (structure)|breakwater]] island. Roughly {{convert|232|km|abbr=on}} of shoreline was created. The World's overall development costs were estimated at $13 billion [[Canadian Dollar|CAD]] in 2005.
The archipelago consists of seven sets of islands; [[Europe]], [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[North America]], [[South America]], [[Antarctica]], and [[Oceania]].<ref name="Atlas Obscura 2016">{{cite web | title=The World Islands | website=Atlas Obscura | date=September 26, 2016 | url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/world-islands | access-date=July 8, 2018}}</ref> Each artificial islands are named for their representative regions, including those representing [[countries]], [[landmarks]], and [[regions]] such as the [[United Kingdom]],<ref>{{OSM|w|186483481|United Kingdom}} {{coord|25.22334|N|55.15937|E|format=dec|name=United Kingdom}}</ref> [[California]],<ref>{{OSM|r|2713321|California|tools=short}} {{coord|25.20300|N|55.14376|E|format=dec|name=California}}</ref> [[Mount Everest]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87185503|Mount Everest}} {{coord|25.23683|N|55.17535|E|format=dec|name=Mount Everest}}</ref> [[Australia]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87185938|Australia}} {{coord|25.23149|N|55.19435|E|format=dec|name=Australia}}</ref> [[New Mexico]],<ref>{{OSM|r|8402261|New Mexico}} {{coord|25.201379|N|55.151797|E|format=dec|name=New Mexico}}</ref> [[Upernavik]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87184344|Upernavik}} {{coord|25.22142|N|55.13939|E|format=dec|name=Upernavik}}</ref> [[Buenos Aires]],<ref>{{OSM|w|202033673|Buenos Aires}} {{coord|25.20106|N|55.1695|E|format=dec|name=Buenos Aires}}</ref> [[New York (state)|New York]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87184265|New York}} {{coord|25.21421|N|55.15101|E|format=dec|name=New York}}</ref> [[Mexico]],<ref>{{OSM|r|8402263|Mexico}} {{coord|25.201824|N|55.154394|E|format=dec|name=Mexico}}</ref> [[St. Petersburg]]<ref>{{OSM|w|200489433|St. Petersburg}} {{coord|25.23475|N|55.16479|E|format=dec|name=St. Petersburg}}</ref> and [[India]].<ref>{{OSM|w|170773643|India}} {{coord|25.23110|N|55.1796|E|format=dec|name=India}}</ref>
==History== The project was unveiled in May 2003 by Sheikh Mohammed<ref name="AB">{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/507983-the-world-islands-in-dubai-completed |publisher=''ArabianBusiness.com'' |title=The World islands in Dubai complete |date=2008-01-10 |accessdate=2008-02-02}}</ref> and dredging began four months later in September 2003.<ref name="AB"/> By January 2008, 60% of the islands were sold, 20 of which were bought in the first four months of 2007.<ref name="Progress Update"/><ref name="AB"/> On 10 January 2008 the final stone on the breakwater was laid, completing development of the archipelago.<ref name="AB"/> As of July 2012, a second island, the Lebanon Island was developed and was 'the only island that has so far been developed commercially, is used for private corporate events and public parties.' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/the-world-is-back-on-dubais-map|title=The World is back on Dubai's map|author=Colin Simpson|publisher=|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref>
==Project difficulties== [[The Times]] Online reported in September 2009 that work on The World had been suspended due to the effects of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|global financial crisis]].<ref name="creditcrunch">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/news/article6831481.ece|title=Credit crunch signals end of The World for Dubai’s multi-billion dollar property deal|publisher=Times Online UK|date=September 12, 2009|accessdate=2009-11-28 | location=London | first=James | last=McLean}}</ref><ref name="darkside">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/johann-hari/the-dark-side-of-dubai-1664368.html |title=The dark side of Dubai |author=Johann Hari |publisher=The Independent |date=2009-04-07 |accessdate=2009-05-16 | location=London }}</ref> And in February 2010 the [[Daily Mail]] reported that the islands had started sinking back into the sea.<ref name=Bates>{{Citation | title = Is it the end of the world? Nasa picture suggests Dubai globe is sinking back into the sea | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1247651/World-Islands-Is-end-world-Nasa-picture-suggests-Dubai-globe-sinking-sea.html | author = Bates, Claire | journal = Daily Mail | accessdate = 2010-04-07 | date=2010-02-02 | location=London }}</ref> This was later denied by Nakheel and independent technical reports as wholly inaccurate.<ref name="McGinley">{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/580782-island-owners-hit-back-at-sinking-claims |title=Island owners hit back at 'sinking' claims |author= Shane McGinley |publisher=arabianbusiness |date=2010-02-04 |accessdate=2010-02-04 }}</ref> Despite the denial, [[The Daily Telegraph]] reported in January 2011 that an independent company, Penguin Marine, provided verification on the erosion of the islands and the silting of the passageways between the islands.<ref name=Penguin>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/dubai/8271643/The-World-is-sinking-Dubai-islands-falling-into-the-sea.html |title=The World is sinking: Dubai islands 'falling into the sea' |publisher = The Daily Telegraph |date=2011-01-20 |accessdate=2011-01-25 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Spencer}}</ref> Due to finance and technical problems, Penguin Marine, the company contracted to provide transportation to the archipelago, is attempting to get out of the annual fees of $1.6 million paid to Nakheel properties.<ref name =Penguin/>
As of early 2011, only one of the islands had been occupied by a building (a show home) on it,<ref name=Sinking/> and commercial or residential properties were not currently being constructed on any of the other islands. Property prices in the Emirates had fallen 58 percent from their peak in the fourth quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=The End of The World|url=http://english.kompas.com/read/2011/01/23/03401537/The.End.of.The.World|work=Kompas.com|accessdate=6 January 2012}}</ref> The world economic recovery from the [[Great Recession]] has resulted in a rebound for the Dubai real estate market: it has been reported that "residential prices [in Dubai] rose by 17.9% from August 2012 to 2013, while rents soared by 14.9% in the same period." <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/november2013/|title=JK Properties Monthly Newsletter (Nov. 2013) "A BRIGHT OUTLOOK FOR DUBAI’S PROPERTY MARKET" |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=November 2013 |publisher=JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref>
Irish investor/businessman John O'Dolan, who purchased the "Ireland" island, committed suicide in February 2009, after his consortium fell into financial difficulty.<ref>{{Citation | title = Extravagant Dubai island project sinks under weight of the credit crunch | url = http://www.independent.ie/world-news/middle-east/extravagant-dubai-island-project-sinks-under-weight-of-the-credit-crunch-1884856.html | date = September 12, 2009 | journal = Irish Independent | last1 = McLean | first1 = James | last2 = McDonald | first2 = Brian | accessdate = 2010-04-07 }}</ref>
==Purchase and development plans== [[File:2010 The World.JPG|thumb|The World 2010 (airview)]]
The World was supposed to be serviced by four major transportation hubs linked by waterways. Land parcels are supposedly zoned for various uses: estate, mid density, high density, resorts and commercial.<ref name="video">{{cite web|url=http://www.theworld.ae/videoGallery.html | title=The World Video Gallery|author=Nakheel}}</ref> A Dubai Infinity Holdings construction planner has stated that developers have been negotiating with Nakheel about temporary siting of a cement batching plant on one of the islands to supply subdivided construction.<ref name="national3quarters">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/property/the-world-three-quarters-sold-out|title=‘The World’ three-quarters sold out|author=The National Newspaper}}</ref>
The plan was for utilities to be routed under water, with water plants at each of the hubs pumping fresh water to the islands. Power was to be supplied by the Dubai Grid and distributed through underwater cables, however as of February 2015 no cables had been laid, so that developers currently have to provide their own power from diesel generators. Waste water and refuse systems are an individual concern for each island.<ref name="video"/>
Nakheel Group is itself further developing a resort named Coral Island over 20 islands that make up the North American part of The World. The low-rise development will include a marina and hotel village.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uaeinteract.com/docs/Nakheel_unveils_super-luxury_resort_at_Coral_Island_of_The_World/25125.htm|title=Nakheel unveils super-luxury resort at Coral Island of The World |date=2007-03-05|publisher=National Media Council UAE|accessdate=2008-03-26}}</ref> The second largest confirmed development is the purchase of 14 islands that make up Australia and New Zealand by Investment Dar of [[Kuwait]]. The islands are being [[terraforming|terraformed]] to be developed as a resort named [[OQYANA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asiatraveltips.com/news05/134-TheWorld.shtml|title=Nakheel sells Australasia segment of The World|date=2005-04-13|publisher=AsiaTravelTips.com|accessdate=2006-12-29}}</ref>
Irish business consortium Larionovo had plans to develop the [[Ireland]] island into an Irish-themed resort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theislandofireland.com/|title=The Island of Ireland|accessdate=2007-07-23}}</ref> The plans include a large internal marina, apartments and villas, a gym, hotel, and an Irish-themed pub. In July 2007 it was announced that the Ireland Island would feature a recreation of [[Northern Ireland]]'s [[Giant's Causeway]]. However, on 25 November 2008 a provisional liquidator was appointed to Larionovo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.larionovo.com/ |title=Larionovo }}</ref> The islands of [[Great Britain]] and [[Moscow]] on The World were acquired by Premier Real Estate Bureau in the Summer of 2008. News was leaked in a [[Daily Mail]] article of January 2009, refuting claims that Great Britain was owned by [[Richard Branson]], [[Rod Stewart]] or John O'Dolan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Homesick Balham boy buys Britain-shaped island for £43m |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1120695/Homesick-Balham-boy-buys-Britain-shaped-island-43m--8211-London-pub.html |publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=2009-04-08 | first=Martin | last=Delgado | date=2009-01-17}}</ref>
In April 2008, Salya Corporation announced that it had acquired the islands of Finland and Brunei in The World and planned to develop them into fashion-themed resorts. Salya spent about [[United Arab Emirates dirham|Dh]]800 million ($218 million USD) to purchase the islands and plans to spend a further Dh2.4 billion ($654 million USD) on development. Brunei Island will be turned into a [[Fashion TV]] resort and Finland Island will be turned into a fashion community called FTV palace.<ref>{{cite web |title=World's Finland and Brunei to be hub of fashion |url=http://www.business24-7.ae/articles/2008/4/pages/worldhub.aspx |publisher=Emirates Business 24/7 |date=2008-04-24 |accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref>
Safi Qurashi, the seven-time multi-millionaire entrepreneur <ref>Leftly, Mark. ''Anger over pay is just the free market in action'', [[The Independent]] 10 June 2012</ref> at the head of Premier, and his business partner Mustafa Nagri, paid an estimated $64 million USD for the {{convert|11|acre|ha|adj=on|order=flip}} piece of land; he was later convicted for non-payment of cheques and sentenced to seven years in jail.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/23/dubai-safi-qurashi | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Rajeev | last=Syal | title=Owner of Dubai's 'little Britain' jailed for non-payment of cheques | date=2010-07-23}}</ref> However, on appeal he was later found not guilty and released from prison in July 2012 when he was declared innocent of two of the three charges.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/exclusive-two-safi-qurashi-judgements-quashed-466985.html | location=Dubai | work=Arabian Business | first=Shane | last=McGinley | title=EXCLUSIVE: Two Safi Qurashi judgements quashed | date=2012-07-23}}</ref> and <ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/expat-money/9423555/Briton-Safi-Qurashi-has-convictions-overturned-in-Dubai.html | location=London | work=The Telegraph | first=Leah | last=Hyslop | title=Briton Safi Qurashi has convictions overturned in Dubai | date=2012-07-24}}</ref> On the final charges the civil court final judgment showed he owed no money, was a victim of fraud and vindicated him completely by awarding 10.8 Million USD to be paid back to him by his former partner who had defrauded him.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/dubai-s-safi-qurashi-cleared-of-bouncing-2-7m-cheque-489328.html | location=Dubai | work=Arabian Business | first=Claire | last=Valdini | title=Dubai's Safi Qurashi cleared of bouncing $2.7m cheque | date=2013-02-13}}</ref> and <ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/safi-qurashi-s-former-partner-ordered-repay-10-8m-by-dubai-court-529323.html | location=Dubai | work=Arabian Business | first=Ashford | last=Fernandez | title=Safi Qurashi’s former partner ordered to repay $10.8m by Dubai court | date=2013-12-04}}</ref> Safi Qurashi is still the owner of GB Island and continues to live and run his businesses in Dubai and is still confident of developing the Island of GB into a unique destination.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-32193-interview-not-the-end-of-the-world-safi-qurashi/ | location=Dubai | work=Construction Week | first=Hannah | last=Raven | title=Interview: Not the End of the World, Safi Qurashi | date=2015-01-17}}</ref>
Josef Kleindienst and his firm JK Properties are developing The Heart of Europe, a collection of seven islands (Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, St. Petersburg, Main Europe, Switzerland and Monaco) in the European section of the World, into an island luxury resort.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Heart of Europe|url=http://www.thoe.com/|accessdate=14 February 2016}}</ref> The resort is meant to create a fully immersive European experience, with outdoor snow,<ref>{{cite news|title=Heart of Europe in Dubai: Streets with snow|url=http://www.emirates247.com/property/heart-of-europe-in-dubai-streets-with-snow-2014-01-20-1.535342|accessdate=14 February 2016|publisher=Emirates 24/7|date=20 January 2014}}</ref> and stores accepting only the EURO as a currency.<ref>{{cite news|title=VIDEO: Plans to make it snow in Dubai are not a gimmick, says CEO|url=http://7days.ae/plans-make-snow-dubai-not-gimmick-says-ceo|accessdate=14 February 2016|publisher=7Days}}</ref>
==Timeline of construction== {{See also|List of Developments on The World Islands}} [[File:The World on 1 May 2007 Pict 4.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Undeveloped islands on 1 May 2007]]
[[File:The World Archipelago April 2015.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Undeveloped islands on 11 April 2015]]
*May 2003: The World development was announced by Nakheel, total completion scheduled for 2008. It was initially to have 200 islands and an area of {{convert|60000000|sqft|m2|order=flip}}.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com">{{cite web|author=Dubai FAQs |url=http://www.dubaifaqs.com/the-world-dubai.php |title=The World Dubai |publisher=Dubaifaqs.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *February 2004: It was announced that The World would comprise 260 islands, and its area would be 6 km by 9 km, with an area of {{convert|250|-|900000|sqft|m2|order=flip}} for each island, with {{convert|50|-|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} of water between each island.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *August 2004: It was announced that land reclamation would cost at AED 7.3 billion ($2 billion).<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *April 2005: Sand dredging 55 percent complete, 88 islands had been completed.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *30 March 2006: [[Richard Branson]] appeared at a media conference on the [[Great Britain]] island. However, this was to announce direct [[London]]-to-[[Dubai]] flights by [[Virgin Atlantic]], and was not related to his investing in the project.<ref>{{cite web|author=smh |url=http://www.asiatraveltips.com/news06/303-TheWorld.shtml |title=Sir Richard Branson 'Stakes his Claim' on The World in Dubai |publisher=Asiatraveltips.com |date=2006-03-30 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *October 2006: Seven-time [[Formula One]] World Champion [[Michael Schumacher]] was presented with one of the islands by Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum on the occasion of his final [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]], in Brazil. Schumacher's manager [[Willi Weber]], suggested, "Perhaps he'll build a [[kart racing]] track on [the island].<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *December 2006: The World reclamation 90 percent complete.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *October 2007: Nakheel announced the sale of Ireland, and Shanghai in October 2007.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *15 November 2007: [[Brad Pitt]] and [[Angelina Jolie]] were reported to have purchased the island ''Ethiopia''{{according to whom|date=December 2015}}. The claim has since been refuted.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jacobs|first1=Frank|title=The World (Under Construction)|url=http://bigthink.com/strange-maps/the-world-under-construction|website=BigThink|publisher=The Big Think, Inc.|accessdate=22 December 2015|date=2014-10-30}}</ref> *January 2008: The World breakwater is completed.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *19 February 2008: Cinnovation Group acquired a {{convert|37000|m2|sqft|adj=on}} island as part of a project valued at $200 million USD. Guest and residential villas and a hospitality complex are planned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europe-re.com/system/main.php?pageid=2343&articleid=10631 |title=Cinnovation acquires Nova Island on The World (UAE/SG) |publisher=Europe-re.com |date=2010-06-01 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> [[File:Artificial Archipelagos, Dubai, United Arab Emirates ISS022-E-024940 lrg.jpg|thumb|left|Artificial archipelagos, [[Dubai]], United Arab Emirates]] *25 February 2008: Dubai Multi Commodities Centre announced that it will establish a {{convert|6000|m2|sqft|adj=on}} [[pearl hunting|pearling]] and marine entertainment center in association with Paspaley Pearling Corporation. It will be located on an island in the Antarctic region of The World.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/148011.html |title=Dubai unveils 'Pearls of Arabia' at The World | DMCC |publisher=AMEinfo.com |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *September 2008: Dubai's Limitless announced plans to develop a $161 million USD wellness resort on an island in "Siberia". Pearl Dubai paid $27.2 million USD for a {{convert|1600000|sqft|m2|adj=on|order=flip}} island nearby.<ref name="thenational.ae"/> *28 December 2008: Turkey Island was bought by MNG Holding in June 2008 for $19 million USD.<ref name="thenational.ae">{{cite web|author=- Saturday |url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/property/the-world-three-quarters-sold-out |title='The World' three-quarters sold out - The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date=2012-06-06 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *28 December 2008: China's Zhongzhou International announced that it will be developing a hotel resort on Shanghai island.<ref name="thenational.ae"/> *28 December 2008: Nakheel said 70 percent of The World had been sold.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *October 2009: An Emirates Business report on 13 October 2009 that 2 islands were sold in July and August 2009.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *December 2009: Dubai based Kleindienst Group said they would start construction of the Heart of Europe in early 2010, according to a press report of 17 December 2009. Islands include Austria, Germany, Netherlands, St Petersburg, Sweden and Switzerland.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *January 2010: On 28 January 2010 Emirates Business reported that Major Trade had started development of their projects on an island in the Greenland area, a villa and hotel resort.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *23 February 2010: Dubai-based Kleindienst Group started work on the Germany island of The World, according to a press release on 24 February 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/225097.html |title=First developer breaks ground on The World | Real Estate |publisher=AMEinfo.com |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> [[File:The World islands map.svg|thumb|300px|The World islands map, annotated with existing developments]] *17 July 2012: The Royal Island Beach Club opened on Lebanon Island. *6 May 2013: Nakheel announces that an out of court settlement has been reached between itself and developer Kleindienst Group, allowing construction on "The Heart of Europe" to resume.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nakheel.com/en/media/news/the-world-llc-settles-with-kleindienst-properties |title=The World LLC settles with Kleindienst Properties |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=6 May 2013 |publisher= Nakheel PJSC |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> *10 June 2013: Construction began on the island Taiwan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/emirates/dubai-s-the-world-construction-on-taiwan-begins-post-ramadan-2013-06-10-1.509715|title=Dubai's The World: Construction on Taiwan begins post-Ramadan|author=System Administrator|work=Emirates 24-7|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> *2 July 2013: Nakheel announces that settlements "with São Paulo Development Ltd for São Paulo Island and a GCC investor for the purchase of Nord Island", totaling "AED185 million", along with the earlier out of court settlement with Kleindienst Group (valued at AED622 million) have "put The World back on the map".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nakheel.com/en/media/news/settlements-worth-aed807-million-put-the-world-back-on-the-map |title= Settlements worth AED807 million put The World back on the map |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2 July 2013 |publisher= Nakheel PJSC|accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> *10 December 2013: Nakheel announced plans to connect the islands with a road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-25515-road-could-be-built-to-man-made-world-development/#.UsrFm2SzAa4|title=Road could be built to man-made World development|publisher=|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> *January 2014: Kleindienst Group's JK Properties announces that "[w]ork has commenced on The Heart of Europe".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/january2014/ |title= JK Properties Monthly Newsletter (January 2014), "KLEINDIENST GROUP LAUNCHES ICONIC THE HEART OF EUROPE PROJECT" |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= January 2014 |publisher= JK Properties|accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> *January 2014: Website "The Heart of Europe" publishes monthly construction updates for the project.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thoe.com/construction-updates|title= The Heart of Europe - Construction Updates|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= January 2014 |publisher= The Heart of Europe|accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> *February 2014: JK Properties announces that the "Heart of Europe" islands construction is "well underway".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/february2014/ |title= JK Properties Newsletter (February 2014), "The Construction of the Heart of Europe Islands is Now Well Underway"|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= February 2014 |publisher= JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> *7 December 2016: The Heart of Europe project makes major progress when the Dubai-based company JK Bauen, part of the Kleindienst Group, appointed Chinese-based companies Wuchang Ship Building Industry Group and Sino Great Wall International Engineering in a joint venture to develop facilities on the six islands.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fahy|first1=Michael|title=Heart of Europe development at The World Islands off Dubai coast takes major step forward {{!}} The National|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/property/heart-of-europe-development-at-the-world-islands-off-dubai-coast-takes-major-step-forward|work=The National|date=7 December 2016}}</ref>
==See also== {{Commons category|The World}} *[[List of Developments on The World]] *[[OQYANA]] *[[Palm Islands]] *[[The Universe (Dubai)|The Universe]] *[[Dubai Waterfront]] *[[Tourism in Dubai]]
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
